ʾabaya.entry: ʾabàyele də́rya b-réša |  He put his cloak over her (A26:50); ʾɛ́-ga kúlla ʾaġăwáθa šexìye |  kúlla b-ʾabbàye-wawa |  At that time all aghas and elders wore the abbaya gown (A26:47); ʾíman ṱ-ila-nabólle bə̀dra |  m-gu-ʾằra, |  mattíwa ... ʾabàya y-amrə́xwale |  When they took it (the rice) to the threshing floor from that ground, they would lay down what we called a cloak (B5:80).

ʾăbu.entry: ʾăbu-bə̀rqa |  electrician(s) (B10:50); băyánni ʾə́mma bnàθa |  ṱ-áwa ʾăbu tā̀j |  I want for myself a hundred girls wearing crowns (A25:74). In expressions of age: ʾo-yála zòra |  ʾábu ʾəsrì-šənne |  The youth, who was twenty years old (A17:2).

ʾadət.entry: ʾáxni ʾádət díyən hàtxɛla |  Our custom is this (A4:30).

ʾaġa.entry: ʾàġay |  My lord (A25:13); ʾáxa ṱ-áwət basìma |  Sir, if you please (A42:1).

ʾa-ġða.entry: Denoting the accessibility of a referent in memory: txárət ʾa-ġða-báxta k̭óre t-wáwa gu-màθa? |  Do you remember the blind woman who was in the village?

ʾahwāl.entry: xázəx ʾahwalə́ttət màlka |  Let’s see what the circumstances of the king are (A8:80); dìya |  ʾahwalə́tte šuxlə̀pla |  Now circumstances have changed (B5:72).

ʾajəbuθa.entry: xzéli xá-məndit ʾajəbùθa |  I have found something amazing (A8:16); xzélən ʾajəbùθa! |  We have seen a miracle! (B9:21).

ʾal.entry: ʾal-ʾằra |  on the ground (A21:5), ʾal-rùše díye |  on his shoulder (A22:18).

ʾalaha.entry: škìra-ʾalaha |  God be praised; ʾálaha ṱ-áwe mənnɛ̀xu |  May God be with you (A8:29); b-àlaha |  By God; mə́ra ha? |  mə́ra b-àlaha! |  She said “Is it so?” They said “Yes” (A38:2); ʾálaha mbasə̀mlux |  May God cure you; ʾálaha manìxle |  May God grant him rest; ʾálaha mazyə̀dle May God increase it (the food in your house - said by guest to the host after a meal); ʾíθwa lìθwa |  biš-m-aláha góṛa lìθwa |  There was or there was not, there was no greater than God (opening formula of a story) (A4:1); xá-yoma mən-yománət ʾaláha one fine day (literally: one of the days of God) (A48:2); tíwɛle xáṣət súse dìye |  ʾu-ya-ʾálaha zìlɛle |  He sat on the back of his horse and off he went off (A28:9).

ʾalahuθa.entry: xzígən ʾalahùθa |  See what a miracle! (A51:21).

ʾălīq.entry: súse b-gáne măzidle ʾălìqe |  A horse by itself increases its fodder (D:34).

ʾalma.entry: bréla ðá xadúθa gu-d-ò-ʾalma |  A (great) joy arose among the people (A4:56); ʾaw-ʾálma ṱ-íle jmíya tàma |  The crowd of people that is gathered there (A26:64).

ʾalpa.entry: tre ʾalpe two thousand; ṭḷaθa ʾalpe three thousand; ʾína ʾalpàye maymúne píše táma |  Thousands of monkeys had appeared there (A14:43); m-ʾálpa ʾáxni lá raba-ʾi-mapəlxə̀xwala |  We rarely used it (literally: in a thousand (times) we did not use it much) (B10:18).

ʾama.entry: only in: brət ama (pl. bərtamwaθa) (distant) cousin (m.) (second degree and more distant) and bratət ama (distant) cousin (f.).

ʾamara.entry: ʾáyya mártət ʾamàre |  This is what they say (literally: This is the saying of the sayers) (A32:24).

ʾamra.entry: ʾámrət màlkɛle |  It is the order of the king (A8:9).

ʾănaha.entry: xzáyət ʾănáha naše-ṱ-íla ráqa bàθri? |  Do you see those people who are running after me? (A7:17).

ʾani.entry: kúlla ʾan-waríðəx qăṭə̀nna |  ‘I shall cut all those roots of yours’ (A25:64). Used anaphorically: šwíqle zúze díye táma zìlle. |  θéle xa-xèna, |  ʾan-zúze šqilíle ʾu-zìlle. |  He left his money there and went off. Another man came. He took that money and went off (A15:15). xárθa ʾáni mə́ṭyela tàma |  l-márzət yàma |  Then they arrived there, by the shore of the sea (A14:37).

ʾaniða.entry: dúkθət xamɛ́θət ʾanìðe |  a place for burying the deceased (B3:19)

ʾanna.entry: ʾánna ʾálpa-w xamšá-mma dìyuxila |  ʾánna ʾálpa-w xamšá-mma dìyila |  These one thousand five-hundred are yours and these one thousand five-hundred are mine (A1:20). Used anaphorically: rába gáye wítɛla ʾánna məndiyàne |  Many times such things happened (B5:163).

ʾan-xa.entry: Denoting the accessibility of a referent in memory: txárət ʾán-xa xonăwáθa k̭óre t-wɛ́wa gu-màθa? |  Do you remember the blind brothers who were in the village?; txárət ʾan-xa-tré t-mutəpqíwalən b-ġðàðe? |  Do you remember the couple that we brought together? (A4:45).

ʾap.entry: (1) also | ʾap-àna mjaṛbə́nna |  ḥàð̣ð̣ díyi |  I also shall try my luck (A1:4); ʾàp-təmməl ʾáxləx mə́nna |  We could eat them also tomorrow (A2:2); ʾap-xmárey šqìləlla |  They took also their asses (A7:15); xuš-pɛ́šən képa ʾap-àna |  Let me also become a stone (A8:55); ʾap-šlàma lɛ́la də́ryəlle |  They did not offer him even a greeting (A15:13); ʾáp-xa lɛle-mṣáya mbasə̀mla |  Nobody (literally: even one) can cure her (A4:12).; (2) connective particle | combined with a topical constituent at boundaries of discourse sections: ʾap-aw-zìlɛle |  xíša mə́ṭya kəs-màlka |  So, he went and he entered into the presence of the king (A1:6-7); ʾáp-awwa sìqɛle gu-ṭúra |  So, he went up into the mountains (A4:1-2); ʾáp-awwa qəm-parmìle |  So, they slaughtered him (A15:9-10).

ʾapɛθa.gloss: cloth put over bread when it is stored

ʾapṣa.entry: ʾilanət ʾapṣe oak tree (mɛša) bearing such gallnuts; hot-píša ʾápṣa milàna |  You have become a green gallnut (i.e. you have not been seen for a long time) (D1:4).

ʾaqara.gloss: area of cultivated land → ʾqr to dig up, to plough

ʾaqla.entry: xaṣət ʾaqla top of the foot; ʾărət ʾaqla bottom of the foot; dawɛ́ra ʾíðe-w ʾàqle |  A mule (is a man’s) arms and legs (B5:124); šə́ryəlla ʾáqle w-ìðe |  He untied the legs and arms (A10:13); ða-ʾáqla rēš-d-àyya ʾɛ́nən |  ʾu-ðá rēš-d-àyya |  We shall treat you with respect (literally: one leg on this eye of ours and one on this other one B9:10).

ʾaqolta.gloss: rope lock used to tighten a rope holding the burden on the back of an animal
ʾaqolta.entry: This consisted of a triangle of p̣aṛma wood through which the ends of the rope were threated and and then pulled tight.

ʾaqra.gloss: trunk of a tree; stem of plant; bottom (of ear)
ʾaqra.entry: xəzyali l-ʾaqrət tena I saw her by the trunk of the fig tree (C2:24); ʾárya mə́xyəlle šaqqána l-ʾəqər-náθət dèwa |  The lion clouted the wolf on the root of his ear (A42:2); ʾəṣrà ʾaqráre |  ten stems (of tobacco plants) (B7:13); ʾəqrət ṭura the foot of the mountain.

ʾăra.entry: ʾăráθe díye zărèwala |  He cultivated his lands (B5:73); măṛòyənwala |  gu-ðà-ʾăra |  I was grazing it (the mule) in a certain piece of land (B5:131); ʾo-gavána bēl-ʾắra |  l-ʾằra |  The boundary area is between one plot of land and another (B5:131); xákma har-damxíwa l-ằra |  Some would sleep only only the floor (B5:204).

ʾăraq.entry: ʾăraq xɛlanta strong arak; ʾắraq mpalṭə̀xla |  m-yabìše |  We produce arak from raisins (B5:12).

ʾarba.entry: ʾurzət ʾarba the fourth man; baxtət ʾarbe the fourth woman

ʾarbaθn.entry: base for pronominal suffixes: ʾarbaθnən the four of us; ʾarbaθnɛxu the four of you; ʾarbaθnéy the four of them.

ʾarbušeba.entry: ʾarbušeba xəška, ʾarbušeba b-lɛle Wednesday night

ʾarda.entry: ʾardət ṣawle sole of shoes; ʾărəd ʾaqla bottom of the foot; ʾardət bɛθa the floor of the house; ʾárde díye kúlla képe góṛe pàrše |  Its (the church’s) floor was all large flat stones (B14:5).

ʾareta.gloss: algae and detritus floating on stagnant water
ʾareta.entry: put in gaps between stones in a garra to seal in the water

ʾarəšwɛrəš.entry: ʾíθwa ʾarəšwɛ́rəš benaθéy There were dealings between them

ʾarxa.entry: mare ʾarxe hospitable man; də-háyyo puš-ʾàrxi ʾədlɛ́le |  Come, be my guest today (A8:42); ʾɛ́ka pɛ́šən ʾàrxa? |  Where can I stay (A26:26); ʾána hon-ʾə́θya ʾárxa kə̀slux |  I have come as your guest (C7:3).

ʾarθa.entry: only used in oaths: hàtxa ṱ-óðən b-ʾárθux |  (I swear) by your rival wife that I shall do it.

ʾašəquθa.entry: kəmət jawja b-ʾašəquθa naše nabli šəkkuθa Whenever she moves coquettishly, people become suspicious (C2:73).

ʾaṣərta.entry: ʾaṣə́rta θìθɛla |  bắyi ṱ-áxli xa-ràmša |  The evening came and they wanted to eat dinner (A2:2); y-oðíwa ʾaṣràre |  They would hold evening celebrations (B5:18).

ʾaṣi.entry: ʾánna hóla ʾàṣi ʾə́lle díye |  They are rebelling against him (A12:58); ṭúra ʾàṣile |  The mountain is difficult.

ʾasira.entry: kulla dwiqe jundiye ʾasire All (the grooms) were taken as captured soldiers (C3:4).

ʾaskăraya.entry: xə́zyəlla ʾán ʾaskăràye |  He saw the soliders (A25:79); xamša-ʾəmmà ʾaskărayáθa bnáθa kúlla |  five hundred soldiers, all girls (A25:74).

ʾaṣya.entry: jwanqone drɛla l-ʾaṣya She has caused the young men embarrasment (C2:59)

ʾatiqa.entry: ʾaw-bə́nyɛle m-jálde ʾatìqa |  It was built in very ancient times (B14:2).

ʾatko.gloss: piece of stomach of a young goat used to make rennet

ʾatkore.entry: The aim is to shoot marbles into a hole in the ground (B11:28).

ʾatuna.entry: y-oðíwa ʾatùna, |  qá-t mtarṣíwa kə̀lša |  They set up a furnace to make gypsum (B5:182).

ʾaθṛa.entry: gu-ʾaθṛa in the home country; lɛ́wət d-áwwa ʾàθṛa |  You are not from this land (A25:82).

ʾavi.entry: zruta avi irrigated cultivation, xəṭṭe ʾavi irrigated wheat (opposite of dēm, demi, dema unirrigated)

ʾaw.2.entry: hálli ʾo-kθàwa |  Give me that book (which you are holding). Used anaphorically: ʾíθwa xa-málka gu-ða-màθa. |  ʾo-màlka |  ʾíθwale tə̀rte bnáθa |  There was a king in a village. That/the king had two daughters (A25:1); ʾo-Barzə́kko zíla dmìxa |  Barzəkko went and slept (A12:10); ʾaw-ṃəḷyále tópe díye spày |  He loaded his gun well (A31:7).

ʾăwaha.entry: y-ásqəx mɛ́θəx míya mən-d-ăwàha ṭúra |  We shall go up and fetch water from that mountain over there (A39:9); mə́re kɛ̀le bɛ́θa díya? |  ... mə́ra ʾăwáʾha qáṣra ṱ-it-xzàyəlle |  He said ‘Where is her house?’ ... They said ‘That villa that you can see over there’; (A40:11) gu-măḥàll-ži |  kút-yum gánu kθɛ́θa d-àwwa, |  ʾɛ́-ga y-azə́lwa féka d-ăwàha |  Every day in the neighbourhood he would steal the chicken of one person, then go (and steal) the fruit of another (A14:7).

ʾawqana.entry: Mắmo-w Zíne hóla npíle gu-ʾoqàna |  Mămo and Zine are in a predicament (A26:51).

ʾawwa.entry: yába là dámxəx gu-d-áwwa qáṣra. |  dámxəx l-wằdər |  Let’s not sleep in this palace. Let’s sleep outside (A12:11). Used anaphorically: ʾíθwa xa-màlka. |  ʾáwwa málka xzéle xa-xə̀lma |  There was a king. This king had a dream. (A1:2); ʾáwwa zílɛle b-ʾùrxa |  He went on his way (A17:12).

ʾawwal.entry: ʾáwwəl dórta the first round (B10:13); ʾáwwəl ma-t-ràxəθ |  as soon as it boiled (B10:87).

ʾaxči.entry: (1) just, only | xúwwe ʾáxčile múdwa rìqa |  The snake just managed to escape (A1:15); ʾáxči ʾáp ʾayya-béna múrri mòdile |  Just one more time tell me what it is (A1:18); malàxe yắði, |  ʾàxči |  Only the angels know (A4:9); ʾáxči xoš-qàyəm |  xazyánne xàmša daqíqe, |  ʾan-xéne kúlla ṭla-d-àw |  Just let him rise for me to see him for five minutes, and all the other (sixty years) be for him (A4:49).; (2) but | ʾə́č̣č̣i-u ʾə̀č̣č̣a, |  ʾáxči ʾána max-xšàwti, |  ʾáyya kìsta |  hóle mxožə́bnəlla max-xà |  (There are) ninety-nine (coins), but according my opinion, he has reckoned this bag as one (A6:3)

ʾaxxa.entry: ʾàxxa ṱ-áwən dmíxa |  I shall sleep here (A10:5); plúṭ m-àxxa! |  Leave here! (A12:5); ʾu-táwra píšle mangóle ʾáxxa l-tàmma |  The ox began to limp back and forth (A22:3); qedámta qímtɛla bràta-w |  mxŭláltəlla ʾay-dùkθa |  ʾáxxa-w tàmma |  In the morning the girl got up and cleaned the place, and so forth (A17:27). Repeated to express movement: xa-núra ʾə́θyɛle b-lɛ̀le |  ʾax-ʾáxxa sàqa |  A light came in the night, coming up here (A29:23). With temporal sense: mu-ṱ-óðəx m-áxxa-w hàtxa? |  What can we do from now on? (A8:59). Used with pronominal suffixes: ʾáxxi hóle mràya |  It hurts me here (literally: My here hurts); ṣléla béʾe ʾàx-ʾaxxe díye |  The eggs ran down him here and here (literally: his here and here) (A23:8).

ʾaxxane.entry: kú-t-̭ile ferə́ssa ʾáθe ʾàxxane |  Whoever is a warrior, let him come here (A29:59); ʾína réši šmíṭa ʾaxxàne |  My head was injured around here (B5:132).

ʾay.entry: Marginally attested in indirect questions: ʾáti xázət ʾày-mənna bắyət |  See which one you like (A14:80).

ʾay.2.entry: ða-kista-xéta max-d-áy yawə̀nnəx |  I’ll give you another purse like that one (you are holding) (A4:15-16). Used anaphorically: ʾímət mṭéla ṭúnte dìye, |  θéle xa-nàša, |  qəm-šaqə̀lla ʾɛ-ṭúnte díye |  When its fruit became ripe, a man came and took its fruit (A17;33); ʾu-ʾɛ-Lelíθa θèla |  The Leliθa came (A19:4); ʾáy píšla tàma |  She remained there (A19:6).

ʾăyaha.entry: réšux mattánne gu-d-yàha káwe |  ṱ-íla pyàša |  I shall put your head in that opening over there that remains (A25:62); zílla dwíqla náwba l-ăyàʾha qunjə́lta t-hódəx |  They went and kept a guard in that far corner (A18:3); mattíwala gu-d-ɛ́ məššára ... ʾə́ṣra gu-d-àyya, |  ʾə́ṣra gu-d-yàha |  They would plant them in the paddy field ... ten in this (row), ten in that one (B7:13).

ʾayya.entry: qu-šqúlla ʾáyya skìnta |  Get up and take this knife (A15:8). Used anaphorically: ʾíθwa xá bàxta, |  ... ʾáyya bàxta |  kùt-yum |  goyàwa, |  maxláwa ṭla-bróna dìya |  There was a woman ... Everyday this woman would beg to feed her son (A14:4); ʾàyyɛla, |  čú-mdi xéna lìθən |  That is it. There is nothing else (that is possible) (A4:43).

ʾazəduθa.entry: ʾána mbáqrən mə́nnux ʾazədúθa yàtwən |  I ask you for permission to sit down.

ʾăzīz.entry: yà ʾăzízi |  my dear (A7:17); ʾăzizət ləbbi my dear; ʾăzizət xone beloved of his brother (C4:6)

ʾazla-kuše.entry: Literally: spinner of distaffs, so-called because it rotates around water.

ʾazola.entry: ʾazolət kuša weaver who uses a spindle

ʾeða.entry: (1) festival | ʾéðux brìxa! |  May your festival be blessed!; y-óði ʾèða |  They hold a festival (B6:22); ʾeða goṛa the Great Festival (Easter); ʾeðət qyamta the festival of resurrection (Easter); ʾeða zora the Small Festival (Christmas); ʾeðət be-yalda Christmas; ʾeðət musarde festival commemorating the baptism of Christ (100 days after Easter); ʾeðət ṣliwa Festival of the Cross (13<th> of September).; (2) festival visit | xaðríwa náše ʾeðăwàθa |  People would go around (the village offering) festival blessings (B10:3); zavrə́xwa ʾeðăwàθa |  We used to go around (the village offering) festival blessings (B6:13); mšɛrìwa |  ... jwája l-ʾeðăwáθa d-an-xène |  They would begin to go and make festival visits to other people (B5:63); qamáye y-azə́xwa l-ʾéðət qàša |  First we would go and offer a festival blessing to the priest (B6:14).

ʾeliθa.gloss: fat tail of sheep; fat of the tail
ʾeliθa.entry: p̭azesór b-ʾəlyàθa |  big red eared sheep with fat tails (A7:22); ʾelíθa qalə̀xwa |  We would fry the tail fat (B10:1).

ʾenir.entry: pɛšət ʾenir lɛle You are (like) the lily of the night (C4:14).

ʾetanaya.entry: gu-d-ánna tre-ʾumràne |  xə́lmət ʾetanɛ́θa y-oðə́xwala gáwe dìye |  In these two churches we used to hold church services (B1:6).

ʾɛba.entry: ʾɛ̀bɛle |  It is shameful; lɛle-ʾɛ́ba ʾəllì? |  Would not that be a shame on me? (A8:55).

ʾɛna.entry: (1) eye (pl. ʾɛne) | murmə́lla ʾɛ́ne dìye He raised his eyes, ʾu-ʾɛ́ni-žigən hóla bṣìre |  My eyes have deteriorated (A24:10); xonăwáθi θéla qam-ʾɛ̀ni |  My brothers have come to mind (A18:12); rába xzìθa ʾɛ́ne díye |  m-d-ò-məndi |  He had suffered a lot from that affair (A18:32); garət ʾɛna eyelid.; (2) aperture (pl. ʾɛnaθa) | in a field boundary for the introduction of irrigation water: dwíqle ʾɛ́nət xáqla b-màssa |  He closed the irrigation aperture of the field with a pole.; (3) spring of water (pl. ʾɛnaθa, ʾɛnăwaθa) | ʾɛ́na hóla nwàʾa |  A spring is welling up, ʾƐ̄n-Nune Spring of Fishes (village name), ʾɛ́nət K̭ùtto |  ... ʾɛ́nət ʾùmra |  the spring of K̭utto ... the spring of the church (the two water springs in ʾƐn-Nune B10:61); ʾu-píšla rəš-ʾɛ̀na |  She remained at the spring (A25:57); zílle rəš-ʾɛ̀na |  He went to the spring (A15:2).; (4) Idioms: gu-d-ànna ʾɛ́ni bṱ-áθən |  (I promise) by these eyes (of mine) that I shall come (A22:20); ða-ʾáqla rēš-d-àyya ʾɛ́nən |  ʾu-ðá rēš-d-àyya |  We shall treat you with respect (literally: one leg on this eye of ours and one on this other one B9:10).

ʾɛnəkθa.entry: in shoes, through which a srap (gaðilta) is inserted; in the middle of a grind-stone (pənxa).

ʾɛni.entry: (1) who? | ʾɛ̀nile? |  Who is he? (A2:7); ʾɛ̀ni híwle-lləx? |  Who gave it to you? (A4:19); ʾɛ́nile qṭìləlle? |  Who has killed him? (A15:16).; (2) which | ʾɛ́ni mənnɛ́xu ṱ-àzəl? |  Which of you will go? (A30:1); ʾɛ̀ni-mənnən |  biš-šapìrtɛla |  Which of us is most beautiful (A25:17). Modifier of a noun: ʾɛ́ni báxtɛla mubrɛ̀θa? |  Which woman has given birth? (A25:6); ga-ʾɛ́ni Zìne |  ʾáxni lɛ̀ðəx |  Now, which Zine we do not know (A26:61); pə́nxa ʾɛ́ni mənnɛ̀le? |  Which of the (types of) grind wheel is it? (B5:92).

ʾɛnta.gloss: airhole of oven; hole in a wheat storage bin (kwara) to take out the wheat

ʾɛwa.entry: míya m-ʾɛ̀we šáte |  He drinks water from the clouds (= He is arrogant); in 1st person boasting about own power: ʾu-ʾána míya m-ʾɛ̀wən štáya |  I can drink water even from the clouds (I have such power) (A26:34).

ʾɛwana.entry: dúnye hóla ʾɛwànta |  It is cloudy.

ʾəč̣č̣a.entry: ʾurzət ʾəč̣č̣a the ninth man; baxtət ʾəčča the ninth woman

ʾəč̣č̣aθn.entry: base for pronominal suffixes: ʾəč̣č̣aθnən the nine of us; ʾəč̣č̣aθnɛxu the nine of you; ʾəč̣č̣aθnéy the nine of them

ʾədda.entry: ʾay-ʾắra máre ʾə̀ddɛla |  That ground is full of weeds.

ʾədlɛle.entry: ʾə́dlɛle dámxəx ʾàxxa |  Let’s sleep here tonight (A4:29).

ʾəjara.entry: ʾáxni šáqləx ḥáqqət ʾəjàra mə́nne díye |  We shall receive wages from him (A14:15).

ʾəjbona.entry: hár ʾəjbóna dìyux-ile |  It is your will (A9:4).

ʾəlla.gloss: unless, only if, except, but, particle of insistence; or not (§19.5.5.).
ʾəlla.entry: (1) unless | b-ču-ʾúrxa ʾo-Dəmdə́ma lɛ́ šaqlìtule |  ʾə́lla qăṭítula míyət Dəmdə̀ma |  By no means will you capture Dəmdəma unless you cut off the water of Dəmdəma (A11:17); xə́tna lè-y-axəl |  ʾə́lla qablíle xà-məndi |  The groom would not eat unless they pledged something to him (B10:40); là qɛṣə́nne káwsux, |  ʾə́lla ṱ-amrə́tli ʾánna ma-brinànela gu-réšux |  I shall not cut your hair, unless you tell me what these wounds are on your head (A29:5-6).; (2) only if | ʾána míθənwa l-márya ʾalàha |  ʾə́lla ṱ-aθyáwa báxta bàθri, |  ṱ-azànwa |  I had sworn to the Lord God that only if a woman came after me would I go (A8:94).; (3) except | combined with a negator = only: w-ána hon-mə́rta ṭla-Nozàli |  ʾána le-gáwrən ʾə́lla xóna díya Gozàli |  I said to Nozali that I would only marry her brother Gozali (A8:95).; (4) but, but rather | ʾu-čú bəṛ-náša la-máṭəlla ʾə́lla b-rzáyət gána-diya ṱ-àθya |  Nobody can reach her, but rather she comes of her own will (A8:65).; (5) particle of insistence | ʾə̀lla gáwrət |  You must marry (A16:6); ʾə́lla xazyánne xòni |  I must see my brother (A8:66).; (6) or not | ʾáw lɛ́ðe čádrət bábe díyila ʾə̀lla |  He did not know whether it was his father’s tent or not (A28:33).

ʾəmma.entry: tre ʾəmma ~ tre-mma two hundred; ṭḷaθa ʾəmma ~ ṭḷaθa-mma three hundred; ʾáwwa ʾə́mma mən-ʾə́mma ʾíle Fàrxo |  This is a hundred percent (=certainly) Farxo (A25:45); zìlela |  ʾəmmáyət náše mɛθóye Bə́lbəl Hazàr |  Hundreds of people went to bring back Bəlbəl Hazar (A8:30).

ʾən.entry: (1) if | ʾən-pálšəx mən-d-áni qaṭlìlən |  If we fight with them, they will kill us (A14:44); ʾən-lá-ʾazən mšàyðən |  If I do not go, he will go mad (A4:27); ʾən-kpìnni, |  ṱ-axlə̀nne |  If I get hungry, I shall eat it (A23:5); ʾən-íle mìθa, |  gắrəg mɛ̀θən |  If he is dead, I must die (A8:61); ʾən-ʾíθ pàwxa, |  ʾi-marmíle gu-hàwa |  If there is wind, they raise it in the air (B5:97); ʾə́n-in ʾàna ʾə́θya gu-šwíθəx, |  qrɛ́gən xaddàməx |  If I have come to sleep in you bed, call your servants (A26:4); máṣət ṱ-óðət rába məndiyáne mə́nne dìye, |  ʾən-ila zawdàne |  You can make make many (other) things from them, if they are left over (B5:219). Complement of the verb ‘to wait’: sàpri |  ʾən-háwe pàwxa |  They wait for there to be wind (B5:97).; (2) either/or | là-barya |  gànwi |  ʾən-sàlbi |  They cannot steal or plunder (A29:39); ʾən-qaṭlə́nnux ʾáyya bráta šaqlə̀nna |  ʾən-la-pálṭən m-àxxa |  Either I shall kill you and take this girl or I shall not go out from here (A29:28); ʾən-ile-qṭìla, |  ʾən-ile xìla |  He has either been killed or he has been eaten (by wild animals) (A39:17); lɛ́la ðáʾa módi bràya, |  hadíya pɛ́ša kèpa |  ʾə́n la-pɛ́ša kèpa |  She did not know what was happening, whether she would now turn to stone or not turn to stone (A8:73).; (3) interrogative particle | ʾə́n máṣət šaqlə̀tla? |  Can you take it? (A39:9).

ʾənwa.entry: ʾənwe kome black grapes; ʾənwə baṣirana type of grapes (slow to ripen); ʾənwe zarrək type of yellow grape

ʾəqba.entry: ʾəqbət ʾaqli heel of my foot

ʾərba.entry: ʾərwət xware sheep; ʾərwət kome goats; ʾərwət wala wild goats, ibexes

ʾərwana.entry: wídle xa-ʾərwàna |  He did a good deed

ʾəryana.entry: gu-ʾəryàne |  in rain storms (B5:124); bás l-ʾəryàna zăríla |  They sow it relying only on rainfall (B5:94).

ʾərzala.entry: made of wood with bedding of grass and hay: ṣlele m-ərzala čira He got out of bed in a temper (C2:38).

ʾəspa.entry: šqílli zeðáye b-ʾə̀spa |  I borrowed some flat-breads; šqílli xə́ṭṭe b-ʾə̀spa |  I borrowed wheat; híwle zeðáye b-ʾə̀spa |  I lent some flat-breads. Not used for the loan of money → dyn (III m-dyn).

ʾəsra.entry: made of willow cane (xelape) or twigs from the mulberry tree (tuθa)

ʾəstaðta.entry: mə́ra: |  xadàmta! |  béna ʾəstàðti |  She said ‘Servant!’ (The servant said) ‘(I am coming) at once, madam’ (A37:13).

ʾəṣər.entry: ʾəṣərila It is very cold; ʾəṣər brizta dry cold

ʾəṣra.entry: ʾurzət ʾəṣra the tenth man; baxtət ʾəssər the tenth woman.

ʾəṣraθn.entry: base for pronominal suffixes: ʾəṣraθnən the ten of us; ʾəṣraθnɛxu the ten of you; ʾəṣraθnéy the ten of them.

ʾəšrāf.entry: ʾána ṱ-óðən ʾəšrāf ʾəllèy |  I shall look after them (A8:18).

ʾəšta.entry: ʾurzət ʾəšta the sixth man; baxtət ʾəššət the sixth woman.

ʾəštaθn.entry: base for pronominal suffixes: ʾəštaθnən the six of us; ʾəštaθnɛxu the six of you; ʾəštaθnéy the six of them.

ʾəzla.entry: guttət ʾəzla a ball of yarn; ʾə̀zlɛle zqíra |  It is knitted with yarn.

ʾiða.gloss: hand; handle; arm; foot (of an animal); round of a game.
ʾiða.entry: (1) hand | ʾíðux lá-darət gu-nùra |  t-là-ʾaqða |  Do not put your hand in the fire, lest it burn (D2:8); b-ʾíðe díye dawùqle |  He would hold it in his hand (B6:3); zríyənwale b-iθàθi |  I had cultivated it with my hands (A17:32); b-ìðən xɛṭə́xwa |  We would sew by hand (B10:59); hállule l-ʾìði |  Hand him over into my custody (A28:25).; (2) handle | ʾiðət tăra handle of a door; ʾiðət magreta the handle of the shaving knife.; (3) arm | dawɛ́ra ʾíðe-w ʾàqle |  A mule (is a man’s) arms and legs (B5:124); šə́ryəlla ʾáqle w-ìðe |  He untied the legs and arms (A10:13).; (4) foot (of an animal) | qímle tàwra |  primále ðá ʾíðe dìye |  He cut off one of the feet of the ox (A22:3).; (5) round of a game | kəmà ʾiθáθa mṭáləx? |  How many rounds shall we play?; ṭḷà-ʾiθaθa muxsə́rre Mắmo |  Mămo lost three rounds (of chest) (A26:66).; (6) Idiom: l-ʾiθàθux |  in your presence (A12:29).

ʾiðamta.gloss: sister of husband; wife of brother of husband

ʾiman.entry: (1) interrogative particle: ʾíman ṱ-àθət? When will come?; hal-ʾíma dàməx? |  Until when will he sleep? (A12:8); bắyən t-yắðən ʾána ʾíman mɛ̀θena |  I want to know when I shall die (A16:1).; (2) Governing temporal subordinate clause: ʾíman ṱ-àθyət, |  ða-kista-xéta max-d-áy yawə̀nnəx |  When you come back, I’ll give you another purse like that one (A4:16). ʾiman-t >ʾimə(t): ʾímət xílla ʾap-o-t-trè, |  píšla xà-šabθa, |  tré šabbàθa, |  kpìnna |  When they had eaten the second one, a week, two weeks went by and they became hungry (A20:9); ʾímə zílle kəs-màlka, |  díwənt málka hóle ṃḷíθa náše ràbe |  When he went to the king, the audience chamber of the king was full of many people (A17:31).

ʾina.entry: (1) presentative particle | in association with verbs of perception: ʾə́θyela xə̀zye |  ʾína ṭéna kúlle ṃə́ḷya šə̀xta |  They came and saw that the saddle bag was completely full of filth (A7:11); qímela zíle xə́zye ʾína dū̀s |  They went and saw that it was true (A14:13); xazéle ʾína bɛ́θe ṃə̀ḷya |  He sees that his house is full (A21:8); paθə̀xle tắra, |  ʾína xazéle ʾo-ʾažvána tàma |  He opened the door and saw the caretaker there (A22:43). Implied verb of perception: mátti bála gu-yàma, |  ʾìna |  ʾa-sústət yamàθa |  nabòləlla |  Čəlkằze |  They looked at the sea (and saw) the mare of the seas taking away Čəlkăze (A12:34); ʾo-xabúša pθìxtəlle, |  ʾína ʾisə́qθa dìya |  She opened up the apple and (saw) her ring (A4:19). Introducing preliminary background material: ṭḷáθna hon-yíwtəlla mòʿəd. |  ʾína ṱ-áθi làxxa. |  ʾáti kúl fàtra |  mṭašə́tla gánux baràye |  I have made an assignation with the three of them. Now, (when) they come here, each time you hide yourself outside (A22:21-22). Climactic result: ṣléla tàma. |  ʾína kúlla gɛ́rme díya šmìṭe. |  She went down there and all her bones were broken (A20:4). In commands: ʾína m-báθər maqðàli |  ʾaw-qə̀ṭma |  šaqlìtule |  mxamìtule |  Now, after she burns me, take the ashes and keep them (A26:85).; (2) but | drawing attention to something unexpected: ʾána bắyənwa šaqlə́nwali xáčča mə̀šxa |  ... ta-ṱ-áxlən b-ʾùrxa |  xáčča mə́šxa-w lə̀xma |  ʾína ʾíði ṣéla gu-d-áwwa hə́nna lìnta |  I wanted to take a little oil to eat on the way, a little oil and bread, but my hand has got stuck in this thing, the pot (A23:8); ʾə̀θyela, |  plíṭe bárqul mðitèy. |  ʾína mðitéy kúlla mxíθa l-kòma |  They came out opposite their town. But, their town was all covered in black. (A4:28). In exclamatory constructions: ʾánna ṣàli |  ʾína mò ṣáli |  They went and what (a surprise when) they went down! (A25:13); xá-bena plíṭṭɛla xa-bràta. |  ʾína mù-brata! |  Then a girl came out, but what a girl! (A13:11); xílənna ʾína mòdi! |  I have eaten it, so what! (A2:11).; (3) otherwise | ʾána hon-márəllux b-àyya šárṭ ʾaláha t-yawə́llux, |  ʾína là-yawəllux |  I am telling you, God will give to you on this condition, otherwise he will not give to you (A3:5).

ʾinta.entry: ʾilanət ʾinta a tree with bunches (qonṭepe) of such nuts

ʾipta.gloss: strap made of gut connecting yoke of animals to the plough

ʾiqa.entry: tắrət gómi ʾìqɛle |  The door of my basement stable is narrow (A7:24); yắðət b-gànux |  ʾìqənwa, |  danànənwa |  You know, by your soul, that I was in trouble, I was in debt (A1:10).

ʾiqara.entry: maṣlɛ́lən b-iqàra |  They bring us down (to the town) with honour (A4:30); ʾáwwa wéwa xa-ʾiqàra |  This was a (sign of) respect (B5:68); ʾána mattə́nnux ʾiqàra I respect you; rába mattə́xwa ʾiqára ʾəllèy |  We felt great respect for them (B15:10); mattə́xwa ʾiqára xa-qa-d-o-xèna |  We used to show respect to one another (B5:229); wéləx hawnànta, |  b-ʾiqárət ṣáwθa basìmta, |  ʾu-màqul |  You have been clever, with the gift of sweet and fine words (A40:16).

ʾiquθa.entry: hóle npíla gu-ʾiqùθa |  He has fallen into distress (A29:29)

ʾisaqta.entry: ʾisáqtət Mšíxa l-šmàyya |  the ascension of Christ to Heaven (B6:7)

ʾisara.entry: ṭúra ʾisáre ramàne |  a mountain with high rocks (A15:13); ma-ṱ-íle ʾisára m-kúlla goyàθa |  since there is such a huge rock on all sides (of the mountain) (A8:48).

ʾisarta.entry: put in foundations of a house

ʾitawa.entry: dúkθət ʾitàwa |  a sitting place, a seat (B6:7)

ʾojəx.entry: goṛət ʾojəx head of tribe; le-y-yawíwa mən-ʾójəx l-ʾòjəx |  They did not give (brides) from one tribe to another (B5:3).

ʾore.entry: qəm-darɛ́le gu-ʾórət susăwàθa |  They have put him in the horses’ manger (A25:11)

ʾorta.entry: The aim is to dislodge marbles in a central target by shooting other marbles at them (B11:25ff.)

ʾo-xa.entry: Denoting the accessibility of a referent in memory: txárət ʾo-xa-náša t-wéwa láxxa qam-šàbθa? |  Do you remember the man who was here a week ago?; ʾána ʾo-xà qáša |  ṱ-ín ʾə́θya gu-Ṭiyàre, |  qəm-doqə́tli xošə́tli gu-gòma |  I am the priest who (you remember) came to Ṭiyare, whom you seized and confined me in the basement stable (B17:15).

ʾumqa.entry: maṣlánnux gu-ʾúmqət yamàθa |  I shall take you down into the depth of the seas (A12:31)

ʾumra.2.entry: kmɛ́le ʾumrùx? |  How old are you?; ʾána ʾŭ́mur díyi ʾəštà-šənnewa |  I was six years old (B15:32).

ʾupra.entry: bắyən t-xazə́nne ʾúpra dìyi |  I want to see my land (A14:47)

ʾurədxa.entry: lá-maxət gúšma ʾurə̀dxa |  Do not punch a needle (D2:59)

ʾurxa.entry: (1) road, way (physical) | b-ʾúrxa tfíqɛle xá-xuwwe bìye |  On the road a snake met him (A1:4); ṣléle ʾurxa-úrxa xzéle ʾína pyáša dəbbòre |  He went down and along the way saw that they were becoming hornets (A10:10); kút-yom dawə́qwala ʾúrxe b-ʾìðe |  Every day he went the same way (A34:29); bálki lɛ́la ʾúrxət dyàṛa |  Perhaps it is the road of no return (A37:10); ʾurxət genawe the Milky Way; ʾurxət šaqiθa the track of a waterchannel.; (2) way (abstract), method | ʾíθwa rába ʾurxáθa mṭawòle |  There were many ways to play (B15:5); dáx ʾúrxa muxzélux ʾə́lla lípla ʾàwwa šúla? |  How did you show her the way to learn this work? (A21:34).; (3) Idioms: báxte díye hóla b-ʾùrxa díya |  His wife is now pregnant (A8:5); báxte díye láwa píšta b-ʾùrxa |  His wife has not become pregnant (A8:5).

ʾurza.entry: ʾúrzət bɛ̀θa |  the man of the house, the householder (B5:117)

baʾuθət ninwaye.gloss: the Rogation of the Ninevites (Assyrian national festival)
baʾuθət ninwaye.entry: Three days fast commemorating the flood of Nineveh (B6:17ff.)

baʿd.entry: báʿd módi xèna? |  Then, what else? (A23:35)

baba.entry: (1) father | bábi muttúle táma bɛ̀θa |  My father set up home there (B8:10); xá-naša l-xóðe lítle la-bába la-yə́mma la-ʾàp-xa, |  ʾáw y-amrìle |  lìtle náše |  A man by himself, who does not have a father, a mother or anybody-he-they say concerning him that he has no relatives (A17:17); bábe díye ʾu-d-áni ʾə̀θyela |  His father and his father’s family came (A4:55); bábən t-šmàyya |  our heavenly father (B8:16).; (2) term of endearment | babi my dear (said by parent to child, or by a person to a friend); ṭla-mòdi bábi? |  Why my dear? (mother to son) (A26:71); mòdi mára, |  bàbi? |  What is he saying, my friend? (A7:25); bábət yə́mmux dear one of your mother (= my dear son) (A37:9).

bădal.entry: qímla ʾáy m-bắdal xmáθa dìya |  She got up instead of her mother-in-law (A21:22).

badoda.gloss: long wooden poker for stirring up the fire of an oven

bahura.entry: mjagra m-kima bahurta She contends with the resplendent Pleiades (C2:74)

băjara.entry: líθ băjàra |  ʾə́lla bṱ-àzəx |  There is no alternative, we must go (A8:27).

baksăma.gloss: big loaf made from flour of wheat

bala.entry: másyəm bàla! |  Pay attention!; másyəm bála l-gànux! Look after yourself!; ʾánna gắrəg xamə̀xla-w |  masíməx bála ʾə̀lla |  We must care for them and look after them (A8:15); mattítu bàla! |  Pay attention! (A8:28); mátti bála gu-yàma |  They looked at the sea (A12:34); máttu bála b-gáne dìye |  nubə́lle rəš-d-o-ṭùra |  He realized that it had taken him onto the mountain (A14:69); Čúxo híwle bále l-bɛ̀θa |  Čuxo set off for home (A7:12); kúlla lɛ̀lela l-bálux? |  Has it been on your mind all night? (A25:67); hál hadíya ʾáwwa məndiyáne píšela l-bàlən |  Until now these things remain in my mind (B15:1); b-álaha l-bàli |  It just occurred to me (A8:41).

balaya.entry: npílli gu-balàya |  I am in trouble, I have a problem; m-ɛ́ka píšlux baláya ʾə̀lli? |  Why are you such a trouble to me? (A17:4).

balki.entry: bálki ʾàθya |  Perhaps she will come (A8:49); bálki lá-ʾawðən xàbrux |  Perhaps I shall not do as you say (A21:43); bálki qam-xa-šàbθɛle ʾə́θya |  He has come perhaps just a week ago (A8:56). Governing a clause introduced by D: bálki ṱ-íla mìθta, |  bálki ṱ-íle xa-mə́ndi θíθa bìya |  Perhaps she is dead. Perhaps something has happened to her (A21:25); bálki yăðálux ʾáti ṱ-it-Gozàli |  Perhaps she knows that you are Gozali (A8:49).

balla.entry: qumta rixana balla Her figure is (that of) an erect odiferous basil (C2:44)

balota.entry: balotət tope muzzle of a gun; balotət pənxa hole of a millstone (into which grain is introduced)

baluṭa.gloss: acorn, nut of fruit that grows on oak trees (mɛša, paṛma) tree

bandək.gloss: harness made of rope used to secure bundles of wood on back of animal

bănude.gloss: swaddling bands (wrapped around baby in a cradle)
bănude.entry: bănúde qmìṭela |  The bands are tied; šaryáwa bănúda dìya |  She untied her bands (A18:1).

baqa.entry: ʾani-míya lɛ́la qa-štɛ̀θa, |  ʾítla bàqe |  This water is not for drinking, it has insects in it.

baqara.entry: dmáyɛle l-xa-rámšət baqàra |  It resembles a cowherd’s dinner (i.e. it is a hotchpotch-the cowherd’s wife used to collect various different items of food from people around the village)

baqloša.entry: tiwex xmala b-baqloše dax-xurəkke We sit and amuse ourselves (by playing with) small stones like friends (C2:31)

baqta.entry: dukθa raba mare baqta a place with many gnats

bara.entry: m-àwwa bára |  on this side (B10:53); xríwla m-kúlla bàre |  It is utterly ruined.

barana.gloss: adult male sheep (four years old and upwards)
barana.entry: šwara barane jumping the rams (game similar to leap-frog B11:15ff.)

barbehn.entry: ṣríxtɛla m-gu-barbèhn |  She called out of the window (A25:59).

barbēn.gloss: open space in front of house

barða.entry: barða b-qanane heavy hail; ða gəmbəltət barða a hailstone

bărəkθa.entry: pšúṭla ʾàqlux |  qắdər bărə̀kθux |  Stretch your legs according to your cloth (D1:6)

bar-eli.entry: m-pálgə d-áw ʾu-bàr-eli |  from its middle and upwards (A8:58); múrməlla ʾaqláθa l-bàr-eli |  ʾu-réša xtàya |  They lifted her legs upwards and her head downwards (A27:34).

barju.gloss: channel connecting sections (sadde) of a paddy field

barmiya.gloss: water weed (growing in rice paddy fields)

baṛ-našuθa.entry: baṛ-našuθət ʾƐ̄n-Nune the people of Ɛn Nune

baroqa.entry: mxéla baróqe gu-xàṣi |  I have shooting pains in my back.

ba-roža.gloss: side of the mountains on which the morning sun shines
ba-roža.entry: ba-ròža |  ʾáy šəmšɛ̀θɛla |  The ba-roža side is sunny (B5:148); ʾan-ṱ-íla ʾíða č̣àple |  ʾíla ba-ròža |  The ones (mountains) on the left are (known as) the ‘sunny side’ (B3:1); y-asqə́xwa gu-ba-ròža |  We would go up onto the ‘sunny side’.

bar-qamaya.entry: This was tied round its front legs to prevent a load from falling backwards when it went up hill → bar-xaraya.

barša.entry: barši my namesake (mode of address to somebody of the same name as that of the speaker).

bar-təxti.entry: prùmle |  m-áxxa-w bar-tə̀xti |  Cut it from here downwards (A14:67); gášəq bàr-təxti |  He looks downwards (A28:3).

bar-xaraya.entry: This was tied around its hind legs to prevent a load from falling onto its neck when it went down hill → bar-qamaya.

barziva.entry: used to strike fire with metal instrument known as manquš

bas.gloss: only; no more; if only; only if; but.
bas.entry: (1) only | Governing clause constituent: bas-yə̀mma ʾíθwale |  He had only a mother (A21:3); bas-ànən šríṭa |  They have all been killed. Only I have escaped (B19:8); bas-mìya máttət qam-réša díya |  Place only water by her head (A21:37); bas-ʾɛ́ni t-xzéla ʾày xoš-ʾáza gu-jahànnam |  Only my eye, which saw it-let that go to Hell (A16:2); ʾánna júlle dìye xə́zye bás |  We only found these clothes of his (A14:17).; (2) no more |. mattátla xa-kawázət míya kəs-réša-w bàs |  Put out for her a jar of water by her head and no more (A21:10).; (3) if only | Clausal connective: xuš-mɛ̀θən |  bas-xáθi Nozáli xazə̀nwala |  Let me die, if only I could see my sister Nozali (A8:57).; (4) only if | bas-ʾánna xonăwáθi bàsmi, |  gorànnux |  Only if you cure these brothers of mine, shall I marry you (A34:22).; (5) but | Clausal connective: ʾɛ́ne pθìxtɛla, |  bas-ṭlìya hóle |  His eye is open, but he is asleep (A31:6); lɛ̀le-xəzya čù-náša |  bas-yắðəx hóla tlíxe ʾánna bàte |  Nobody has been seen, but we know that the houses have been destroyed (A29:52). Before a reduced predication: ʾax-sinìyele |  bas-gòṛa |  It is like a tray, but (it is) bigger (B6:45).

base.entry: base buse b-draya He is making all kinds of disparaging remarks (A50:2)

basəsta.gloss: dish of crushed wheat cooked with husks

basima.entry: (1) pleasant, beautiful | dúnye basìmtɛla |  The weather is pleasant; ʾu-qále díye rába basìmɛwa |  His voice is very beautiful. (A25:43-44); ʾáθṛa rába basìmɛle |  It is a very pleasant place (B5:148); rába ʾítley xayúθa basímta bəd-àyya |  They had a very good life on account of this (B5:106).; (2) delicious, tasty | kəma-basìmtɛla ʾixála! |  ‘How delicious the food is!’ (A21:31); lɛ̀la basíme ṭla-xála |  They are not good for eating (A43:3).; (3) healthy | málka ṱ-áwət basìma |  King, may you be well (A1:14); réšux ṱ-áwe basìma |  May you (literally: your head) be healthy (said to a person who has been recently bereaved); basima raba Thank you very much (basimta raba said to a woman); háwət basíma ràba |  qa-d-áwwa ʾixála ṱ-it-yíwəlle qa-dìyi |  Thank you very much for this food that you have given me (A22:31); ʾàyya basímta |  She is the one to thank (A14:96); gánux basìmta! |  Well done! (A39:21).; (4) sharp | púmmət maqára basìmɛle The mouth of the gouge is sharp.

basimuθa.entry: ʾálaha yawə́llux basimùθa |  God grant you good health.

bassa.entry: yába dɛ̀ṛəx. |  bàssa, |  wídlən ṣɛ̀da, |  bàssa. |  Let’s return. That’s enough. We have done some hunting. That’s enough. (A4:6); bássa bxɛ̀gən |  bássa wuð-tàzi |  Do not weep any more! Do not mourn any more! (A26:88); bássa mgàləj! |  Stop talking nonsense!; bássa ští ʾu-rwì! |  Don’t drink any more and get any more drunk! With pronominal suffixes (§8.20.2.): bassi I have had enough; bassux You (ms.) have had enough; baswali I had had enough; bàssi m-xáye |  I have had enough of life (A8:59); bàssən mə́nne |  We have had enough of him (A41:2); ʾána ʾə́mma bàssi |  A hundred is enough for me (A1:6).

baste.gloss: expanse of stones in dried up river

baṣirana.entry: ʾə́nwə baṣírana qarùṭela |  The baṣirana grapes are tough.

baṣora.entry: (1) little, small (in quantity) | zrúta rába baṣórta ʾìθena |  There is very little cultivation (B5:75); b-kúlla yóma zór maṣìwa |  xàzdi |  xá-mdi rába baṣòra |  In the whole day they can barely harvest something very little (B5:144).; (2) a few | baṣóra mənnèy |  ʾi-pɛšíwa yáʿni t-la maṭíwa ʾɛ́kɛle bɛθèy |  A few of them remained without arriving at their house (B15:44).; (3) biš-baṣora less | hálli zúze biš-baṣòre |  Give me less money; ; taqríban ʾo-bíš-baṣora ʾànənwa šqíla |  It was I who received almost the least (B1:19).

baṣore.entry: rába baṣòre xazə́nne I rarely see him.

baška.gloss: white mark on forehead of sheep or horse

băṭăna.gloss: inside of wall facing into the house
băṭăna.entry: as opposed to paθət guda front of wall, facing outwards

baθra.entry: ʾána qamɛ̀θa |  ʾu-Zíne bàθra |  ʾu-Səttíye xarɛ̀θa. |  ‘me first, Zine behind and Səttiye last’ (A25:19); la-baθra, la-bara backwards

baṭila.entry: ta-mút baṭíla tíwa gu-bɛ̀θa? |  Why are you idle sitting in the house? (A39:1); sə́twa baṭìle-wɛwa náše |  In winter people were unoccupied (B11:12).

baṭila.2.entry: It is used to carry č̣ita (butter) as a lubricant for sharpening implements on a məšna (whetstone).

baṭoya.gloss: piece of baked bread crust that falls from the wall of the oven

bawa.gloss: window without glass; open balcony of house
bawa.entry: In winter it was blocked with woven wicker (gədla)

bawar.entry: ʾána lítli báwar ʾə̀bbe |  I do not trust him.

bawaruθa.entry: ʾána bawarúθi θáya biyɛ̀xula |  My trust is in you (said by bride to the family of the groom) (B5:41)

bawsa.gloss: piece of matting (xaṣira) connecting beam between the oxen (qaṭira) to remainder of the plough

băxət.entry: bắxət ʾaláha dìyux |  I implore you (to forgive me) (A1:18); bắxət ʾàlaha! |  For God’s sake! (do sth. for me/us).

baxta.entry: baxtət babi, băxət babi my step-mother.

baza.entry: tre-bàze |  šwirìle Qaṭína |  Qaṭina leapt two bounds (A50:10); xa-báza rìqle |  He ran with one bound.

baza.2.entry: mən-báze bára bazbùze |  ʾu-m-bazbúze bára bàze |  From great people little insignificant ones grow, and from insignificant ones great ones grow (D2:57); bazi qṭille neriya My lord (lover) killed a male goat (C2:18).

bazbuza.entry: mən-báze bára bazbùze |  ʾu-m-bazbúze bára bàze |  From great people little insignificant ones grow, and from insignificant ones great ones grow (D2:57).

bazəkka.entry: hóle sxáya b-bazə̀kke |  He is swimming the crawl.

bazəkka.2.entry: qălúnka bazə́kka díya rìxa y-awéwa |  The stem of the pipe was long (B7:19).

be-băxət.entry: báxta be-bằxət-ila |  The woman is not trustworthy (A4:3); ʾána lán-mirəllux be-bằxət-iwət |  I did not say that you are dishonest (A1:21).

be-baxtuθa.entry: xzélux be-baxtùθa |  You have seen something unfair (A2:10); t-là-ʾamrət ʾána wáðən |  be-baxtùθa ʾə́llux |  Don’t say that I am being deceitful to you (A13:8).

bečiya.entry: qá-t-yátwəx qam-bečìye |  in order to look after the lambs (B5:226)

be-ḷaye.gloss: upper room, room on first floor of a house

bena.entry: (1) breath | graša bena to take a breath; gríšle béna rìxta |  He took a deep breath; tré-gaye gríšle bèna |  He took two breaths; hóle šqála bèna |  He is breathing; píšta bénux l-hàwa |  You are panting.; (2) time, instance | tre bene twice; raba benaθa many times; xà-bena ʾázi náše |  People should go (only) once (B15:91); har-wéla taq-táq mxàya |  ʾu-taq-tàq, |  xá-bena-w trè, |  w-áwwa sqìdle |  They made a taq-taq knocking noise, taq-taq, once, then twice, then he became fed up (A14:68); ku-bénət šátən čáy dɛ́rən šékər gàwa |  Every time I drink tea I put sugar in it; ʾáyya bèna |  ʾə́n ʾamrə̀nnux |  pălə́tla pálga mə̀jjəd? |  This time, if I tell you, will you really divide them in half? (A1:12); čú-bena lat-ṭlíbta hátxa məndiyáne díya hot-ṭlàba! |  You have never requested such things are you are requesting now (A26:45); kut-mɛ́θela ʾána t-yánne zùze |  ʾax-ṱ-in-híwəlle xa-béna xèta |  I shall give money to whoever brings her back, as I gave (money) once before (A27:30). xa-bena for a while, after a while, then | tíwela xá-bena hàdəx |  They sat for a while like that (A26:17); zàlɛwa, |  xá-bena xzéle m-rə́ḥqa xá-mdi xwàra |  He was going along and then he saw in the distance something white (A14:28). xa-bena xeta/xena again | xá-bena xéta qìmela |  qèdamta |  Again they got up in the morning (A21:16); ṣlàya, |  ṣálya šátya mìya, |  ta-t-qàlba xá-bena xéna |  She went down to drink water and then finally returned again (A33:8).; (3) yes | mə́ra: |  xadàmta! |  béna ʾəstàðti |  She said ‘Servant!’ (The servant said) ‘Yes, madam’ (A37:13); qəryali mərra bena I called her and she said “Yes” (C2:24) → mare bena

beṛa.entry: béṛɛle qam-tằra |  It is light outside.

beta.entry: beʾe swiye coloured eggs; qɛ́mi mxáya bèʾe |  They begin to knock eggs together (Easter custom) (B5:58); betət saṭana snail shell.

be-təkke.entry: ʾó-t šawə́rra šáwwa sə̀kke, |  ða-qɛ́θa gu-be-tə̀kke |  He who jumps seven stakes, (one) will hit him in his waist (D2:1). → təkθa trouser cord

be-təlmən.entry: brónux be-tə̀lmənile |  Your son is unruly → tlm

be-xtaye.gloss: lower floor in a house, basement

beza.entry: xa-kísa xwára t-bèza |  a white muslin bag (B6:42)

bɛθa.entry: mu-ṣṭímlux bɛ̀θi? |  Why have you ruined me? (literally: Why have you destroyed my house?) (A15:14); mapəlxíwa náše ṭla-gu-bɛ̀θa |  People used it for their household (B5:171); bábi muttúle táma bɛ̀θa |  My father set up home there (B8:10); bɛθət qəqwane cage for partridges; bɛ̄θ-mìθe tomb (B6:1); be-Bakus the family of Bakus. Adverbial: mɛθɛ́le bɛ̀θa |  They bring it back home (B5:164).

bɛθuθa.entry: sáma zóda ṭla-bɛθuθéy mapəlxìwala |  ṭla-našèy |  Most people used it (the honey) for their household, for their family (B5:178)

bəðya.entry: xa ṭaqət rixana bəðya (She is like) a sprig of luxuriant basil (C2:72).

bəlbala.entry: wírre bəlbàla gawéy They were in chaos.

bəlbəlawa.gloss: celebrations at the end of winter
bəlbəlawa.entry: xaðríwa bəlbəlàwa We would go around (performing) bəlbəlawa (i.e. children go around the village asking for gifts B7:7).

bəllorta.entry: connected to the genitals of a baby in a cradle to carry away its urine

bənyana.entry: ʾáwwa ṃále ṭla-bənyàna |  That is sufficient (firing of the gypsum) for building (B5:184).

bəqqəm.gloss: red powder (prepared from herbs) used to cure eye diseases

bəqra.gloss: cattle (horses, mules, oxen, cows); herd of cattle
bəqra.entry: m-lɛ́l mbàdla |  xalwíwa tawə̀rta |  y-asqáwa bə̀qra |  Early in the morning they would milk the cow and it would go up to (join) the herd (B5:172)

bərgawa.entry: qamáye ʾo-rešáya šaqlə̀xwale |  ta-jùlle. |  ʾo-xèna, |  y-amrə́xxa bərgàwa, |  ʾo-t biš-daqìqa |  First we took the best for clothes. The rest we called bərgawa (inferior quality wool), which was thinner. (B10:49)

bərke.entry: ða-bə́rkət mìya |  a pool of water (A14:77)

bərmalta.gloss: long jacket worn over other clothes

bəṛ-naša.entry: xa-bəṛ-náša lɛ̀la xzáya |  They do not see any human (A14:41); ku-brónət bə́ṛ-naša ʾáθe l-d-áy jăzíra qamàye |  Whichever person comes to the island first ... (A14:46)

bərqa.entry: bə́rqe mxáya gu-šmàyyɛla |  Lightning is striking in the sky; ʾɛ́-ga líθwa bə̀rqa |  At that time there was no electricity (B10:45); ʾăbu-bə̀rqa |  electrician(s) (B10:50)

bəṛ-qatta.gloss: small white worm (found in butter and cheese)

bərqiya.entry: Qaṭína nðéle xo-bərqíyət šmàyya |  Qaṭina jumped up under the lightning of the sky (A50:11).

bərra.entry: hóle θéle Čùxo, |  xa-bə́rra ʾə́rwe bàθre |  Čuxo came, with a horde of sheep following him (A7:21); ʾən-kúlla qəm-maxíla bərrèy |  If they have broken up all their group (B11:9); bərrane (groups), also bərbərrane, name of a game (B11:2ff.).

bərzoma.gloss: cool room for storage in the basement of a house
bərzoma.entry: boyət bərzoma hatch giving access to storage room

bəska.gloss: lock of hair; tress of hair

bəsma.entry: bə́sma dɛ́rɛ gu-pə̀rma |  They put fragrance in a thurible.

bəspora.entry: Băgiya m-bɛθa goṛa muqyamta max-bəspora Băgiya of a great family, brought up like a little child (C6:8).

bəsra.entry: y-oðíwa ... bə́sre They would make meat dishes (B5:13).

bəṣliṣa.entry: xzéle xa-bəṣlíṣa zòra |  He saw a small ray of light (A14:24).

bəšwele.gloss: small hole releasing a water jet from pipe (kotăla) that drives the blades of a water-mill

bəṭma.gloss: terebinth tree; the nut from such a tree

bəθqa.gloss: sweets, rice scattered over newly weds

bəxya.entry: ʾáwwa mò-qalət bə́xyɛle? |  What sound of weeping is this? (A4:44); baxya bəxya marira She weeps a bitter weeping (C2:58)

bəxyona.gloss: little weeping, weeping of a little child
bəxyona.entry: bəxyóna lɛ́le dìyux |  Weeping is not for you (A38:7)

bəzka.entry: šwírre xa-bə̀zka |  He made a little leap.

biba.entry: bibət ʾɛna pupil of the eye

bibəlta.entry: bibəltət ʾɛna pupil of the eye

biš.entry: (1) more, most | With adjectives: ʾína mástət ʾə́rwe rába biš-basimtɛ́la biš-príštɛla mən-d-a-t-tàwre |  But the yoghurt of sheep is much better and more choice than that of cattle. (B5:173); ʾaṣə́rta mɛθɛ́wala ða-dúkθa bíš-qurba t-y-awɛ́wa mìya táma |  In the evening they would bring them to closer place closer where there was water (B5:160); ʾíθən ... biš-xoš-gùṛe |  There are better men (A26:79); ʾíθwa lìθwa |  biš-m-álaha góṛa čú-mdi lìθwa |  There was, there was not, there was nothing greater than God (A30:1); qu-qálbəx bɛ́θa biš-spày |  Come let’s return home-(that is) better (A30:55); múr ʾɛ̀ni-mənnən |  biš-šapìrtɛla |  Say which of us (three) is most beautiful (A25:17); ʾáy biš-xámθɛla m-kùlla |  She is more beautiful than all (= the most beautiful of all)’ (A25:26). Adjective omitted: bíš m-áyya dúkθa ʾɛ̀ka xázəx? |  Where could we find (something) better than this place? (A12:5). With adverbs: qəm-maxéla ʾáqla biš-xɛlàna |  He struck her leg harder (A33:12); dráyɛle biš-hódəx mə́nna díya xáčča xàmra |  He put some wine further up from them (A12:49). With verbs: xáčča biš-šlèla |  She became a little more calm (A4:17); bíš madqə́rre mən-d-ó déwa ṱ-axə́lwa ʾə́rbe dìye |  He (God) valued him more than the wolf that ate his sheep (A10:13).; (2) (not) at all| intensifier of a negator: y-amríwa ʾáw bíš la-mzànzər |  yáwəl ṭéma pàyəšwa |  They said that it does not lose its taste at all. It keeps its taste (B10:76); ʾáp-xa lá-biš-ile-mṣaya mqarów-əlla dìya |  Nobody was able to go near her at all (A4:6); b-qɛ̀ṭa |  bíš liθ-məṭràθa, |  ʾu-bíš liθ-tàlga |  In summer there are no rains at all and there is no snow at all. → zawda, zoda

bišta.entry: šə́mša gànya |  ʾu-bíšta là-ganya |  The sun sets, but evil does not set (with it) (D2:5)

bizər.gloss: herb that is put in jajək

bliga.entry: m-táma hòdəx |  kúlla ʾan-ʾárba yàrxe, |  xámša yàrxe, |  y-áwɛ náše blíge mjămòye, |  mjămóye qa-sə̀twa |  From this time onwards, throughout four or five months, people are busy gathering, gathering for winter (B5:107); har-blígət b-kàsux |  You are always occupied with your stomach (A23:10); blígela b-ġðàðe |  The were preoccupied with one another (A4:50).

b-nəsba (l-).gloss: with regard to; in accordance with

boč̣a.entry: də́ryəlla bòč̣e |  He sewed the seeds (A18:26).

bola.gloss: seed head of millet (prage), sorghum (xroriya) or rice
bola.entry: Such heads do not have the long hairs characteristic of wheat and barley.

b-oma xena.gloss: the day before yesterday; the day after tomorrow

boqa.entry: tawra boqa recalcitrant bull (that buts people)

boqča.entry: made of finer fabric than parzūn.

boš.entry: qála qamáya zílle bòš |  The first cry was in vain (A7:74)

boṭa.gloss: large wooden channel made of willow (xorta) that carries water at high speed to drive water-mill

boya.entry: xá-boyət xùwwe |  a snake hole (A9:6); qam-tằrət |  d-ó-boyət tèle |  before the door of the fox’s hole (A20:6); boyət buma Hole of the Owl (a small cave in the rock near the village of Dure); bóyət xmàṭa |  the eye of a needle (A11:12).

bra-qənna.gloss: egg that is placed under a chicken to stimulate it to lay more

brīn.entry: ʾánna ma-brinànela gu-réšux? |  What wounds are these on your head? (A29:6).

brindar.entry: qəm-maxíli brìndar They injured me; mə́xyɛwən brìndar |  I am injured; Rústam píšle brìndar |  Rustam was injured (A28:28).

brixa.entry: brixa! Congratulations! (general); brixe! Congratulations (on your new clothes)!; ʾéðux brìxa! Happy festival!; qedámtux brìxta |  Good morning!; rámša brixà-llux |  Good night; bríxta ḥammàmux |  I hope you feel better after your wash; hóya brixtà-llux |  May she be blessed to you (said as a blessing on the marriage of a man) (A25:69).

brona.entry: brōn-màlka |  the son of the king (A18:17); lá bnòne |  ʾə́zze maθòye |  The goats were not producing young (A38:1).

bubra.entry: grows on plants such as lagna and ṣamərma.

bulbul.entry: bulbúle jmáʾela l-qàle |  Nightingales gather at his voice (A25:46)

bura.entry: The crops grown in such a field are said to be dema, e.g. xəṭṭe dema unirrigated wheat.

bura.2.entry: xá-burət kèpe |  a pile of stones (A11:5)

burəkθa.entry: After eating food a guest says to the host: ʾálaha dɛ́re burkáθa gu-bɛ̀θux |  May God bestow blessings on your house.

burnuṭ.entry: wíðtənwalux bùrnuṭ! |  I had made you (like) tobacco snuff! (A50:12).

burra.gloss: pot for preserving yoghurt (submerged in water to keep cool) or for storing date syrop (nepoxta) and yeast (xmira)

burrəš.gloss: dish consisting of meat and grains
burrəš.entry: similar to čiče, a dish of meat, millet (prage) and yoghurt.

busama.entry: ʾó-məndit ʾàna xílli |  ʾó busáma mubsə́mli tàma |  là-ʾaθi mtanóye |  What I ate and the enjoyment I had there could not be related (A2:8)

buxara.entry: buxára máṭe l-qarùθa, |  páyəš ṭə́pye ṭə̀pye |  The steam becomes cool and turns into drops.

buxra.entry: buxrət bɛθa firstborn in the family

buxtən.entry: dráya búxtən l-xá l-d-o-xèna |  (He was) slandering this one and that one (A48:5).

bzara.entry: ʾánna bzàre |  these parts of the plough (A30:22)

čadoda.gloss: inviter; man who goes around villages to invite guests to a wedding → čyd

čadra.entry: made of fabric (cf. k̭wina bedouin tent made of goat’s hair): Səttìye |  qímtɛla čádra díya mxìθəlla |  be-pálgət ʾAmedìa |  Səttiye pitched her tent in the middle of Amedia (A25:78).

čakala.gloss: pruning hook; tool used for pulling down fruit and nuts from trees

čakčaka.gloss: wooden wheel shaking and dispensing slowly wheat into a water-mill

čakke.entry: xoni b-šaklile čakke The weapons suit my brother (C5:2)

čale.entry: ṣléla ʾáqla díya gu-xa-čàle |  Her foot went down into a hole (A10:7); zadéle ṣàle |  gu-xa-čále gòṛta |  He threw him down into a deep pit (A22:40); ʾo-t-xápər čále ṭla-xàwre |  b-gàne ṣále gáwa |  He who digs a hole for his friends will fall in it himself (D2:17).

čăpər.entry: ʾó-naša hóle tíwa gu-čằpər táma |  That man was waiting in ambush there (A12:50).

čappa.entry: čappa l-yamne a bend to the right; čappa l-čappe a bend to the left; šaqíθa ʾi-xăðàwa |  čàppa wéwa hátxa |  lɛ́wa də́rəst ràba |  The stream twisted round, it was bendy like this, it was not straight (A8:13).

čappe.entry: čappe ʾu-č̭ure zigzag; ʾáyya ʾúrxa kúlla čáppe ʾu-č̭ùrela |  This path is very winding.

čarək.entry: ṭḷaθa čăwarək three quarters; sáʾət xa-w čàrək a quarter past one; saʾət xa-w čarək a quarter past one; čarək ṭḷa-ʾəṣra a quarter to ten.

čarməkθa.gloss: leather strap along which the spindle (kuša) is run to start it spinning

čarxa.entry: ʾu-zvírtɛla rēš-d-ó-ṭura rēš-d-ó-gəppa xa-čàrxa hátxa |  She went round above the mountain, above the cave in a circuit, like this (A8:76); mxélux xa-čárxa hál zíllux kəs-bàxtux |  You went on a circuitous route and went to your wife (A1:23).

čarxona.entry: xa-čarxona črixwala She took a short turn around (A51:12).

čawərre.entry: tiwa wənwa nṭaraθa čawərrət beriyaθa I was sitting in vigil, waiting for the milkmaids (C2:16).

čay.entry: mɛ́θili tre-čày! Bring me two teas!; čay quwya, čay ranganta, čay mare-ranga strong tea; čay zalalta weak tea; čáy lɛ́la šqílta rànga, |  drí xačča-xéna rànga gáwa |  The tea is weak, make it a bit stronger; čay silani type of tea.

čeri.entry: čeri qamaya October; čeri xaraya November

čeri.2.entry: xa-čeri b-Surma zqira a sash is woven by Surma (C1:19)

čəčča.entry: rešət čəčča nipple; čəččət tawərta teat of a cow; čəččət naθa lobe of the ear; čəččət balota tonsil

čəkka.entry: yále zóre mṭawóle b-čə̀kke The young children were playing with ankle bones (of sheep and goats) (A25:87).

čəldevana.gloss: trigger in the trap known as ṱăp̭əkke, ṱăp̭əkθa

čəlləkθa.entry: xmaθa l-yaṣila zinta. čəlləkθa m-ʾiða šqilta. The mother-in-law is standing by the corner. The pot (representing the household duties of the new bride) has been taken from her hand. (C1:10)

čəlloxe.gloss: crispy pieces of baked bread remaining on the wall of the oven

čəngərta.gloss: small piece of fabric (put on mouth of pot containing jajək) (B14:1)

čərək.entry: də́ryəlla xá čə́rək ʾu-mə̀xyəlla |  He shot one, twang, and hit it (A12:32); har-wáða čŭ̀ruk |  lan-mràʾa |  čú-mdi lɛ̀le-θaya bíyi |  It (the gun) just makes a bang, but I am not hurt, nothing happens to me (B9:18).

čərkənna.entry: čərkənnət bəṣla kernel of an onion

čiče.gloss: dish made from meat, millet and yoghurt

čira.entry: ṣlele m-ərzala čira He got out of bed in a temper (C2:38)

čol.entry: plíṭɛle gu-čòl |  He went out into the countryside (A8:90).

ču.entry: Negative determiner of a nominal: ʾu-ṭlálux lan-šwíqa čù-məndi |  and for you I shall not leave anything (A2:11); čù pəlxána la-pálxət ʾáti |  You shall do no work (A23:32); hon-də́ryəlle gu-xa-čále ʾamúqta lá-ʾaməṣ čù-ga čú-ga paləṭ |  I have put him in a deep hole and he will never be able to come out (A22:41); la-har-ču-dúkθa lìθwa |  She was nowhere at all (to be found) (A27:26).

čuka.entry: čukət qəqwanta the chick of a partridge

čura.entry: with long, silky hair known as marrəs; also known as čurrət marrəs or ʾərwət marrəs.

čurrəkθa.entry: čurrəkθət marrəs female long haired angora goat

čŭrup.entry: ṣə́lyɛle čŭ̀rup |  He came down, thud (A8:40).

čuxa.entry: A coat from this material was worn by men in winter to protect back when carrying loads and to protect body from knife wounds when engaging in warfare. The material was also used for the cloth that was put on the back of a mule (qurṭana).

č̭ənnək̭ɛr.entry: θáyɛle xðárɛle č̭ənnək̭ɛ́rə d-an-nàše |  He comes and rides around those people (A12:5); xăðíle č̭ənnək̭ɛ́re díye gə̀dda |  They wind a thread around it (B11:18); zadáwale kúlla m-gàre |  č̭ənnək̭ɛ́rət swàna |  l-yámne čàppe |  They would throw it all from the roof, around the eves, on the right and on the left (B5:195); ma-t-wɛ́wa ʾə́θye nàše |  č̭ənnək̭ɛ́rət Mšìxa |  ... Mar-Yuḥánna lá-mṣele kút-xa dréle qáwət míya b-rèše |  So many people came around Christ ... that Saint John could not put a scoop of water over everybody (B6:10).

č̭uč̭ana.entry: makrəb č̭uč̭ane n.f. late snow falling at the beginning of the month of March (literally: the one that angers the magpies)

č̣anga.gloss: leather gloves used to grasp thorny plants when harvesting

č̣aple.entry: ʾan-ṱ-íla ʾíða č̣àple |  ʾíla ba-ròža |  The ones (mountains) on the left are (known as) ba-roža (in the sun) (B3:1).

č̣appe.entry: mxaya č̣appe to clap hands in applause

č̣uwa.entry: tuθa č̣uwa mulberry tree with smooth bark

dabaša.entry: ʾíθwa gu-máθa doqíwa dabàše |  ṭla-dùša |  Some people in the village used to keep bees for honey (B5:176).

dabašta.gloss: beehive; family of bees within a hive
dabašta.entry: l-Yawsəp zwinta b-dabašta It has been bought by Yawsəp for a beehive (B8:29). A swarm of bees that leaves the hive is known as a šəlxa.

dabuqana.gloss: parasitic plant growing in trees, from which a gluey substance is extracted to produced birdlime; birdlime extracted from this plant

dalila.gloss: thinly distributed with spaces in between
dalila.entry: gəllále gu-məššára dalìlela, |  lɛ́la ʾamùre |  The weeds in the rice paddy-field are thinly spaced, they are not densely spaced; ṭəlla dalilta light shade (with some sun shining through); káwsi píšle dalìla |  My hair has become thin.

daliθa.entry: ṭarpət daliθa vine-leaves; xa-dalíθət xùwwe |  wild vine (without fruit) (A26:91).

dalopa.entry: qa-t-dalòpe |  la-ṣálɛ b-sə̀twa |  so that leaking drops did not seep through in the winter (B5:146); ʾəθyewəx kope kope qam-məṭra ʾu-qam dalope We have come bending down in rain and drizzle (C1:14).

dalya.entry: dálya dáwəq gújmət ʾə̀nwe |  A tendril bears bunches of grapes.

dama.entry: mṭáləx dàma |  Let us play backgammon; kepət dama backgammon counter

dambus.gloss: type of herb resembling tail of horse

dana.gloss: time; point in time; period of time
dana.entry: mṭíθɛla dane-dìye |  wírre kəs-màlka |  His time came and he entered into the presence of the king (A1:14); dān-dìye |  ṭla-pàya |  It (the dough) is ready for baking (B5:16); dánɛla qarə́nna qálət ṭḷàθa |  It is time for me to call the third cry (A8:59); xá-saʾət qam-dàna |  an hour beforehand (B5:119); kəmà-dana pɛ́šət? How long will you stay? xə́lya ʾi-mjămə́xwa ràba, |  ʾárba dàne |  We would collect a lot of milk, four times (B10:21); har-dána b-danà y-oðíwala |  They would make it from time to time (B10:22); har-d-ɛ-dána at that time (B15:64). Before a clause: mən-d-ɛ́-danət brèla |  hál d-ɛ-dánət mṭéla l-yàla, |  wéla bxàya |  From the time she was born she started weeping, (and continued) until the time that she came to the boy (A25:4); ʾɛ-dánə ṱ-ìla ṛíše, |  ... ʾáwwa məskéna ràba pšímle |  ʾu-ʾáy mšuyðə̀nna |  When they woke up ... he, poor man, became very sad and she became mad (A4:5).

dandəkθa.entry: xa dandəkθət ṭlawxe a lentil seed, a single lentil; xa dandəkθət

danθa.entry: The water contained in such jars was kept cool by wrapping them in wet grass. These were used in Dure, which did not have water springs inside the village.

dapa.gloss: wooden board, plank; wooden beam used on a loom (xanuθa) for keeping the strands tight

dapθa.gloss: small wooden board, strip; one of two leaves of a trap door in a partridge trap (suta)

daqiqa.entry: qamxa daqiqa finely ground flour; ṭmírtɛla ða-dúkθa daqìqta |  She is buried in a tiny place (A38:10)

dara.entry: dárət xámša Már-Gwirgis píšɛle bə̀nya |  (The church of) Mar Gwirgis was built in the fifth century (B1:6).

dăraj.entry: dắraj ḥărára díye its degree of heat, its temperature (B6:37)

dăraje.entry: xa xalqa mən-dăraje one step of a flight of steps.

dărava.gloss: mud dam used to direct irrigation water in a field

daraya.entry: b-tope kəmɛwa daraya! What a skilled shooter he was! (C7:9)

darba.entry: la-máxəx tre-dàrbe |  We do not strike two blows (A50:14) → zarba

darda.entry: ʾàna |  dárdi lɛ́la d-àyya. |  dárdi ʾíla t-ʾá-t gu-panjarìye. |  My suffering is not from this (game), my suffering is from that one at the window (A26:66).

darga.entry: Only build in large houses (qaṣre); ʾaqli l-darga maxyanna I shall kick the door (C1:15)

darjăma.gloss: screen behind which hunters (shooting birds) hide

darta.entry: (1) courtyard, residential enclosure | šqíləlla ṭása b-lɛ̀le |  ʾu-núbləlla zə́dyəlla gu-ða-dɛ̀rta |  They took the bowl in the night, took it away and threw it into a house enclosure (A15:12); dártət ʾùmra |  the churchyard (B1:12).; (2) halo dartət yoma halo around the sun; dárta l-yòma, |  ʾə́rwe gu-gòma. |  dárta l-sèra, |  ʾə́rwe l-ṭèra. |  If the sun has a halo, the sheep will be in the basement stable. If the moon has a halo, the sheep will be in the noon sun. (D2:15).

dartət yoma.entry: dártət-yoma zílla wídla hàdəx |  The next day she went and did the same (A18:3).

darya.entry: xa-dárya nàše |  many people (B5:135); ʾu-ʾíθwa náše xa-dàrya |  There were many people (B5:178)

darza.gloss: large tied bundle of grass or produce

dasiya.gloss: awn, hair of head of corn

dasta.entry: dastət warde a bunch of flowers; xa dastət xəṭṭe a bunch of wheat

dašta.entry: wíðəlwala ʾắra dàšta |  ʾu-maṣíwa náše doqíwa ṭḷà |  ʾarbà-reze xá-xa-gaye |  They had made the ground level and the people could form three or four rows at once (B15:79).

dăvăqa.entry: kawə́dna mxéle dăvắqe bìyi |  The mule bit me.

dawa.entry: ṭéni kúlla ʾíwa mən-dàwa |  My load all consisted of gold (A7:11); ya-ʾàlaha, |  yawə̀tli |  ʾə́mma dàwe |  Oh God, give me a hundred gold pieces (A6:1); ʾána xmáθi xá-dawa zắra muttɛ́θəlli gu-ʾíðət xóni ʾIshəq |  My mother-in-law put a yellow gold coin for me in the hand of my brother Ishəq (B8:35).

dawba.gloss: pure liquid honey (without pieces of honeycomb)

dawɛra.entry: generic term used to refer to both male and female → kawədna (m.), koðənta (f.)

dawla.entry: (1) drum (musical instrument) | dawla-w zorna drum and pipe; músqəlle dáwla-w zòrna-w |  hósa ʾu-gargàrta |  They brought him up (with) drum and pipe, and with clamour and shouting (A4:25); sabóti mubèla, |  píšla dàwla |  My finger has swolen as large as a drum.; (2) drum containing the wheat at the top of a water-mill | open box with a hole in the bottom through which wheat comes out onto the grindstone (B6:54).

dawra.entry: (1) wooden door bolt.; (2) turn (in a game) | ʾap-ʾáwwa pàrəq |  dáwre dìye |  Also his turn is over (B11:8).

dawrane.entry: dawranət kake gums of the teeth; dawrane ḷaye the upper gums; dawrane xtaye the lower gums

dawsa.entry: xzéli dáwsət déwa gu-tàlga |  I saw the footprints of a wolf in the snow.

dax.gloss: how? how could it be? like, just as; when
dax.entry: (1) how? | dáx ʾúrxa muxzélux ʾə́lla lípla ʾàwwa šúla? |  How did you show her the way to learn this work? (A21:34); dàx-it? |  How are you? (A22:16); hà bráti, |  dàx-it, |  dàx-lɛt? |  My daughter, how are you? (said after long absence) (A21:27); dàxi? |  How (could this be)? (A25:69); dàx-it mára? |  What are you saying? (A7:14).; (2) how could it be? | nàša |  dàx la-pălə́nna? |  Man, how could it be that I shall not divide them? (A1:13); mə́re dàxi? |  He said ‘How could that be?’; (3) like, as | Before clause or noun (with pronominal suffixes: daxwaθe): dáx ṱ-in-muθɛ́θəlla ʾa-béna xèta, |  ʾay-béna ʾàna maθyánna |  Just as I brought her before, so this time I shall bring her (A27:30); dax-ṱ-íwət ʾáti hátxa mṣuqàlta, |  ʾap-ʾáw daxwàθax-ile |  Just as you are pretty, so he is like you (A8:67); qa-t-là-hawe sɛ́rga spáy dax-d-áw |  so that there will not be another saddle as fine as it (A8:37).; (4) when | dax-ṱ-ile xə́zyəlla θàya, |  hádəx ṣràxa-w |  xumθàne, |  Čúxo rìqɛle, |  plíṭɛle gu-màθa |  When he saw them coming, shouting and angry, Čuxo ran out into the village (A7:16).; (5) Idioms: dàx lítlux xáṭər |  By all means (I’ll do as you say) (A21:11).

dekonta.entry: t-la-maxyáli dekònti |  lest my mummy beat me (A34:3).

dēm.entry: zruta dēm unirrigated cultivation, xəṭṭe dema unirrigated wheat (as opposed to ʾavi irrigated).

derubər.entry: ʾán dɛrubɛ́re šuréla xá-bena xèta |  The vegetation began again (to sing) (A51:10).

deθa.entry: (1) sweat.; (2) resin, gum formed from the sap of the qaqna plant | This is softened in water then chewed; deθət qərda curative ointment produced from the black resin of the tragacanth shrub (qərda)

dɛna.entry: yáwən dèni |  I shall pay off my debts (A1:8); zílli hiwíli dɛ̀ni |  I went and paid off my debts (A1:11); tálga l-ṭùre |  ʾu-dɛ́na l-gùre |  As snow is to mountains, so a debt is to men (D2:25).

dɛnana.entry: yắðət b-gànux |  ʾìqənwa, |  danànənwa |  You know, by your soul, I was in trouble. I was in debt (A1:10); šmáyya ʾíla denánta ṭla-ʾắra tə́rte qərṭále t-ʾə̀pra |  Heaven owes the Earth two baskets of dust (D1:9)

də.entry: (1) With imperatives and deontic verbs: də-mjămə́xlən jarrèta |  Let’s put together a food-box for ourselves (A30:41); də-šqúl ʾanna-zùze! |  Take these coins! (A1:27); de-ʾə̀dyo, |  qu-pɛ́gən kàde |  Today, get up and bake kade cakes (A30:41); ʾána də-ṱ-amrə́nnox ʾó-mdi-t taxrə̀nne |  I shall tell you what I remember (B15:1).; (2) In deontic questions: de-maxə̀xle? |  Should we beat him? (A14:8); de-màṭo hóya? |  How could that be? (A30:21).; (3) With perfective verbs at boundaries and prominent points in narrative: de-píšla ʾáp-ay báxtə d-àwwa dewə̀rrəš |  Now, she became the wife of that vagabond (A12:38); de-qíma mtúnyəlla qəṣṣə́tte kúlla ṭla-d-o-sàwa |  Now, he told all his story to the old man (A14:76); ʾu-de-b-lɛ̀lela, |  zílɛle zílɛle Now, while it was night, he went off (A22:38).

dəgdin.gloss: metal frame for cooking over a fire (with three legs); the three stars of the constellation Orion

dəmma.entry: ʾáwwa də́mma mattùle |  He sheds this blood (A11:20); ʾáni zúzət bábe dìye, |  də̀mmɛla |  This is the money of his father, it is his blood (money) (A15:16).

dəmme.entry: də́mmət ʾɛ̀na |  the tears of her eyes (A34:5); xa ṭəppət dəmma a tear drop

dəpna.entry: qáyəθ b-o-ṱ-íle də̀pne |  He knocked into the one next to him (A22:34)

dəqna.entry: mṭéle xa-náša sàwa, |  də̀qne |  hal-ʾằra |  mə̀ṭya |  He came upon an old man, whose beard reached the ground (A24:7); dəqnət Nisan the beard of Nisan, a custom whereby on the first day of Nisan (April) a woman pulls up a plant with mud on its roots and sticks it to the roof of the house.

dəqša.entry: táwra qəm-gamə́šle b-də̀qše |  The ox gored him with butts.

dərədya.gloss: pile of snow that has fallen from a roof

dəsqa.entry: (1) handle of a tool.; (2) stem of fruit

dəžmən.entry: lišána də́žmən gàna |  The tongue is its own enemy (D2:32); qáṭu-w ʾaqúbra də́žmən t-ġðàðela |  A cat and a mouse are mutual enemies (A44:1).

dəžmənayuθa.entry: ʾána béni ʾu-bénux dužmənayùθɛla |  We are enemies.

didwa.entry: ʾáyya dúkθa máre didwànela |  This place is full of flies.

didwana.entry: ʾáyya dúkθa didwàntɛla |  This place is full of flies

diga.entry: qám t-qáre ʾax-dìga |  before it calls like a cock (A24:16)

diwən.gloss: gathering of people; reception; audience chamber
diwən.entry: díwən dwìqtɛla a gathering is being held

diyara.entry: xrīw-diyára twirílux bzàre! |  You scoundrel (literally: one whose houses are destroyed, i.e. may you have your houses destroyed), you have broken the parts of the plough!

dolma.gloss: dish of stuffed vine leaves; a stuffed vine leaf

dormadār.entry: dormadā́r kúlla berəšyàθa |  All around there were cushions (B10:80)

dorta.entry: ʾáwwəl dórta the first round (of sieving) (B10:13)

doša.gloss: balcony, low structure attached to outside of house for people to sit on; seats inside a booth (quprana)
doša.entry: generally used in the plural form doše.

drana.entry: cf. ruša upper arm, arm in general

draya.entry: ʾarbí dráye pàrča |  forty yards of material (A28:10); kul səmbəlti xa draya Each (side) of my moustache is a cubit (A51:5)

dudiya.entry: bríxta dudíya ṱ-iwət ʾáti qíma gàwa! |  Blessed be the cradle in which you grew up! (A21:41)

duglana.entry: rába rába duglàna-wewa |  He was a great liar (A48:1); ʾáti duglàntət |  You (fs.) are a liar (A25:20).

duna.gloss: pen for sheltering sheep and goats in winter

dunye.entry: (1) world | ʾáwwa plíṭɛle gu-ða-dúnye xèta |  He came out into another world (A14:26); ʾálaha yállux b-àyya dúnye |  ʾu-b-ɛ-xèta |  May God grant you (bounty) in this world and the next (A21:44).; (2) weather | dúnye hóla ràya |  It is rainy; dúnye hóla ʾɛwànta |  It is cloudy; dúnye hóla mgargòme |  It is thundering; dúnye prèla |  It became light.; (3) Idioms: ʾáy šaqíθa bṱ-áza bṱ-áza nabláley ðá-gotət dùnye |  The stream will flow along and take them somewhere (A8:11); har-máxəx b-dùnye |  Let’s go just go away (A30:41); dùnye qəm-čɛdíla |  They invited many people (A12:23); šúprə dúnye hóle ʾəlla-dìya |  She was of a unique beauty (A13:11); šqéle b-dùnye |  He ran off aimlessly; dùnyela! |  That is life! (A40:13).

duwana.gloss: paste put in cakes made from flour, butter and salt (sometimes with the addition of honey and walnuts); oil (animal)

duxwa.gloss: dish made from yoghurt, barley and meat

duzuθa.entry: yóma mən-duzúθa qìdle bɛ́θa |  One day his house really burnt down (A48:5); xà-yoma, |  har-mítle b-duzùθa |  One day he really died (A27:42).

dwaqta.entry: dwaqtət sɛpa the handle of a sword

dwaṛa.gloss: rest area for sheep in the mountains (under the shade of trees)

dwara.gloss: threshing of grains by animals on the threshing floor

fălăke.gloss: stones of a rapids in a river
fălăke.entry: néra hóle šwára fălằke |  The river is flowing in rapids

farquθa.entry: mút farqùθɛla? |  What is the difference? (A15:12); ʾáw-ile xa-dánət farqúθa bēl-d-áyya l-d-àyya |  This is a time of division between this (season) and the other (B5:115)

farra.entry: mə́xyɛle xa-fárra č̭ənnək̭ɛ́rə d-o-qàṣra |  He made a circuit around the palace (A12:66); xa-fárra bəd-šatə̀nne |  I shall drink it with one gulp (Qaṭina).

făsaduθa.entry: ʾáwwa wídle făsadúθa bḗn ʾaturàye |  ʾu-bḗn barzanàye |  He made trouble between the Assyrians and the people of Barzan (B19:1).

fatra.entry: zílela xa-fàtra |  They went on awhile (A17:3)

fayda.entry: lìθba fáyda |  (A25:32), líba fàyda |  (A18:4) It is no use; leš faydá-lləx qáṭlət gànəx |  It will no longer be of any use to you to kill yourself (A38:16); mùt paydɛ́wa? |  What was the use of it? (B15:40).

feka.entry: ʾítlən féka fə̀rya |  We have abundant fruit (B5:222)

fədwa.entry: fə́dwa ʾə̀llux |  (It was) a redemption for you (said when a catastrophe happens to others) (A23:16)

fəkra.entry: ʾaw-xoš-fə̀krɛle! |  That is a good idea! (A39:11)

fəllən.entry: hà-pəllən |  lɛ̀kət zála? |  Hey so-and-so, where are you going? (A1:11); ʾána síqli fə́llən dùkθa |  I went up to such-and-such a place (A10:9); sí-mur ta-pə́llən wazī̀r |  Go and tell such-and-such a minister (A4:38); só l-bɛ́θət flàn-naša |  Go to the the house of such-and-such a man (A8:8); mót mára fə́llən ʾàti |  What do you, so-and-so, say (B5:9).

fərya.entry: ʾítlən féka fə̀rya |  We have abundant fruit (B5:222); ʾăráθa pə̀ryewa |  Plots of land were abundant (B10:54); qṭilela raba friye Very many were killed (C3:3)

fətne.entry: ṱ-áwəð fə̀tne |  He will make trouble (A29:11).

ga.entry: (1) almost, about to | Combined with verb: ga-ṱ-àθən |  I am about to come; ga-máṭya ṱ-axlàle |  She is about to eat him (A18:26).; (2) connective particle | Signalling temporal sequentiality: rắpili m-an-képe ṱ-íla tàma, |  ga-maxzə́nnux ʾúrxa ṣàlət |  Throw me the stones that are there, then I shall show you the way down (A14:70). Introducing a comment: lá-məre bắye xàθux. |  mə́re bắye Zìne. |  ga-ʾɛ́ni Zìne |  ʾáxni lɛ̀ðəx. |  He did not say ‘He loves your sister.’ He said ‘He loves Zine.’ Now, we do not know (by this statement) which Zine (was meant) (A26:61). At the beginning of direct speech, predominantly questions: ʾámər ga-k̭òra |  ʾána mò yánnux? |  He said ‘Now, blind man, what can I give you?’ (A26:57); mə́ra ga-mo-xə̀ðye b-áwwa dúša? |  They said ‘Why are we so happy about this honey?’ (A14:15).

ga.2.entry: málla Naṣrádin xá-ga băyéwa mbašə́lwa pàča |  Once mullah Naṣradin wanted to cook pača (A5:1); xa-xá-ga (B6:16), xa-xa-gáye (B15:77), gá-gaθa sometimes; b-xšàwən |  ʾáyya quṣàrta |  hár gărəg-máṭe ʾəllì-xa-ga |  I think this cooking pot should eventually belong to me (A5:2); tré-gaye tré wíta ʾàrba |  Two times two equals four; xámša gáye xámša wáyɛla ʾə́sri-w xàmša |  Five times five is twenty-five; raba gayaθa many times; ʾo-gáya qằmɛθa θélux l-kə́sli |  The first time you came to me ... (A1: 22). xa-ga xeta another time, again: xá-ga xéta plíṭṭɛla Lelìθa |  Again Leliθa came out’ (A51:12); then: bắye qaṭə̀lwale. |  xá-ga xéta klèle |  He wanted to kill him. Then he refrained (A10:3-4). ʾɛ-ga at that time, then | ʾɛ́-ga zúze baṣòrewa. |  At that time money was scarce (B5:5); kút-dana ʾa-ṣə́pra mìtle, |  ʾɛ́-ga ʾana-mɛ̀θən |  If ever that sparrow dies, then I shall die (A12:41); là-palṭət, |  hal-t-̭amrə́nnux plùṭgena |  ʾɛ̀-ga pálṭət |  Do not come out, until when I say to you ‘Come out!’, at that time you should come out (A14:67). Governing a temporal clause: ʾɛ́-gət damə̀xwa, |  ṭḷaθà yomáθa |  ʾu-ṭḷaθà lɛlăwáθa háwe dmìxa |  When he slept, he would be asleep for three days and three nights (A29:2). Expressing logical sequence: ʾɛ́-ga ʾáp-ana bắyən ʾàzən |  So, I also want to go (A5:1). Governing a factual conditional (§19.5.8.): ʾɛ́-gət mən-d-ánna hàwe, |  šúla bṱ-ázəl la-qàma! |  If there are these (gold pieces), the job will go ahead! (A4:15).

gabbara.entry: náše gabbàre heroic people (A29:1); gabbare, gebare Orion (constellation): mbáqər kíma-w gabbàre |  ask the Pleiades and Orion (A38:12).

gaðilta.entry: (1) plaited strap of a shoe | This passes through small holes (ʾɛnaθa) in the shoe.; (2) plaited material on the top part of shoes know as lastike

galaya.entry: k̭urra xamra la-štile ... galaya sərre ʾile Boy, do not drink the wine. ... It is the revealer of secrets (C2:10)

găliya.entry: b-ṣlaya galli galli tope šišale ʾəlli While (I was) coming down the valley, he brandished his gun at me (C2:49).

gallək.entry: Only in vocative expressions: hé gállək nàše, |  ʾɛ́ni záwən ʾilàna? |  Hey, everybody, who will buy the tree? (B5:42)

galθa.entry: tawə́rta npílla l-gàlθa |  the cow allowed itself to be mounted by a bull (Betanure galθa stuffed fabric used for bedding)

gamoša.entry: táwra gamóša ʾi-máxe də̀qše |  An aggressive ox butts.

gamura.gloss: sour (e.g. apple that is not ripe, dry), pungent (taste remaining in mouth)

gana.entry: (1) soul, person | ʾən-lá-ʾawðət b-xábra dìyi |  gánux šaqlə̀nna |  If you do not do as I tell you, I shall take away your life (A15:20); ha-gàni, |  lɛ̀kət zála? |  Hey, my soul, (respectful form of address) where are you going? (A15:6); háyyo ya-gáni ṱ-amrànnux |  Come, my dear, let me tell you something (A22:36); də́ryəxxa gʸánən gu-bɛθɛ̀xu |  We have placed our sould in your house (= We beseech you) (B5:4); gánux basìmta! |  Well done! (A39:21); gʸánən basìmta! |  bravo! (B5:154); y-aθɛ́wa m-bár hàdəx |  xámša ʾəštà ganáθa |  Afterwards, five or six peoplewould come (A5:77).; (2) reflexive pronoun | zdíθəlla gána dìya |  kəsle-dìye |  She threw herself down beside him (A37:18); bašlə́xla b-gànən |  Let’s cook them by ourselves (A2:2); ʾáwwa ʾə̀rbi |  m-gáne díye θéle ríqle l-ṭùra |  This sheep of mine has come and run to the mountain of its own accord (A10:3); maxbánət gàne-wewa |  He was a lover of himself (= selfish) (A3:1); Mắmo qímɛle rəš-gàne |  Mămo stood up (A26:5); làn-ṛyaša b-gáni |  I do not feel anything (is happening) to me (B9:19).

gare.entry: ʾən-bábux ʾu-yə́mmux gu-bɛ̀θɛla, |  lɛ́la šəklánta ṱ-ásqət l-gàre |  If your father and mother are in the house, it is not pleasant for you to go up onto the roof (D2:11); l-garăwàθa biš-rába mṭalíwala |  They played it most often on the roofs (B11:29); garət ʾɛna eyelid; š-gárət ʾɛ̀ni! |  by all means!

gărəg.entry: Deontic (must): gắrəg ʾàmrəx |  We must say (A4:38); gắrəg ʾàθət |  ‘You must come’ (A7:9).
