Deontic (supposed to): ʾáxtu mən-zoruθɛ́xu gắrəg pɛšítu tlíqe b-ʾámrət màlka |  In your childhood, indeed, you were supposed to disappear by the command of the king (A8:88); Epistemic: gắrəg háwe làxxa, |  qəm-xazə́nne qam-xámša daqìqe |  He must be here, I saw him five minutes ago.

gargome.entry: šmáyya hóla mxáya gargòme |  The sky is thundering.

garra.entry: mṭéle gárre dìye |  His turn came (A1:7); ha-t-mṭéle gárra ʾə́lle dìye |  until it was his turn (A17:31).

garra.2.gloss: pool in river created by constructing a dam

garšo.gloss: tool used to stir up the mud in the water when planting rice in the paddy fields

garuta.gloss: small stack of twigs or leaves for animal fodder in winter, built against a tree

garuwa.gloss: stack of twigs and leaves for animal fodder in winter
garuwa.entry: garúwət ṭàrpa |  a heap of leaves (A32:22)

garθa.gloss: large sledge for transporting sticks and fodder on snow

gasosa.entry: grows in pods (šənqe) in and uncultivated area (čol)

gaṣ.gloss: meat cooked over a fire on a skewer

gawa gawa.entry: síqle gáwa-gawət ḥadìqa |  He went up through the garden (A17:24); náša jawújwa gawe-gawe-dìye |  palə́ṭwa m-d-ɛ́-paθa xèta |  A person could walk through it (the river) and come out the other side (B3:9).

gawana.gloss: boundary; strip between fields with no cultivation marking boundary
gawana.entry: ʾo-gawána bēl-ʾắra |  l-ʾằra |  The boundary area is between one plot of land and another (B5:131); píšla mxurdéθa m-kúlla gewàna |  It was surrounded on every boundary (B1:15).

gawaya.entry: ṣabota gawɛθa middle finger; mə́re ṭla-d-o-xóne gawàya |  He said to his middle brother (i.e. middle of three) (A24:25); ʾo-gawáyə šqilíle zùze |  The middle one (of the group of three people), who took the money (A15:16).

gawza.entry: bàlki |  képa qítle b-gàwza |  npìlle-ʾăra gáwza |  Perhaps the stone has hit the walnut, and the wallnut has fallen on the ground (= Perhaps I am in luck) (A1:5); gàwze |  šmìṭe |  cracked (i.e. shelled) walnuts (A25:48).

gayasa.gloss: penitent thief (at crucifixion); ceremony held on 2<nd> day of Easter
gayasa.entry: In this ceremony the priest blesses the congregation with a long pole bearing candles; yōm-gayàsa |  the day of the gayasa ceremony (B10:2).

gazənda.entry: la-ʾóðət mə́nni gazə̀nda |  Do not blame me.

gazza.entry: gàzza |  šaqlə́xwa lə́xma bìye |  gu-tanùra |  With tongs we would pick up the bread in the oven (B10:98)

gðalta.entry: gðaltət kore wrestling with one foot in a small hole (If your opponent pushes you over and your foot comes out of the hole, you have lost the game).

gðila.entry: míya mugðə̀lla, |  píšla gðìla |  The water has frozen, it has become ice.

geba.entry: mən-kúl gebàne, |  ʾíθ xa-dàšta |  On all sides there is a plain (B4:1); mən-d-ó-geba xèna |  on the other hand (B15:11); kút-xa xíša l-xà-gēb |  Everybody went in one (= a different) direction (B1:8). m-gēb, gēb in place of, instead of: ʾáyya béna hár-kulla ṭlàlux ʾən-bắyət, |  m-gēb-d-àni |  This time everything is for you, if you want, in place of those (other coins) (A1:13); ʾálaha mxožə́bnəlla m-gēb-xà-dawa |  God has reckoned this bag as corresponding to one gold coin (A6:10); gēb xaθi holi ʾana instead of my sister, it is me (C1:13); ʾap-àti |  m-gḗb ṱ-aθə́twa mɛ́θətwali zùze, |  šqíllux xa-šəndòxa |  So you, instead of coming and bringing me money, took a stone (A1:25).

genawuθa.entry: y-áwəðwa genawùθa |  ʾu-qačaxùθa |  He engaged in robbery and brigandry (A27:1); núbləlle b-genawùθa |  He took it away in stealth.

gesa.entry: mšurɛ́lɛ bnáyəlla batèy |  b-képa ʾu-gèsa |  They began to build their houses with stone and gypsum plaster (B5:179)

gədda.entry: ma-yəmmi zulli gðaðe |  Spin for me threads (A51:3)

gədla.gloss: wattle of intertwined twigs used to make a fence and other structures
gədla.entry: mxéli gə́dla qam-d-áwwa bàqči |  I have built a fence in front of my garden

gəgla.gloss: skein (of wool, thread) spun on a spool (msarbis)

gəlda.entry: xá-gəldət tàwra |  an ox skin (A11:10); mə́xyɛle ʾáqle díye l-ò-gəlda |  He kicked the carcass (A27:43).

gəlya.entry: ʾap-ʾáxxa ʾisàra |  réša har-gə̀lya |  There was a rock here, the top of which was completely exposed (B9:3).

gəmbəlta.entry: gəmbəltət ʾupra ball of earth; gəmbəltət barða hailstone

gəmgəmme.entry: banəx kanune č̣əmme č̣əmme ʾu-ʾəlla mbašləx gəmgəmme Let us build stoves (with) a little (fire) and on them we shall cook delicious foods (C1:5).

gərðo.gloss: dish consisting of yoghurt and cracked wheat

gərəkθa.gloss: hand mill used to remove husks from rice

gərgəra.gloss: type of grass with seed head that is fed to sheep; light snow falling in round grains like the seeds of this plant
gərgəra.entry: dúnye hóla ráya gərgə̀ra |  It is snowing in round grains.

gərkawe.entry: y-azə́xwa gərkàwe |  We used to go hunting partridges (B5:147)

gərra.entry: kút-xa hóle zíla b-xá-gərrət yə̀mme |  Every one went off empty handed (B1:23)

gərse.entry: xa dəndəkθət gərsa a grain of crushed wheat

gəxka.entry: našət gəxka a man who is the butt of jokes; ʾay-ṭawálta mṭalíwala qa-gə̀xka |  They play this game for fun (B12:2).

gəžže.entry: neríya b-gə́žže lè-y-mayəθ |  A male goat does not die (at the sight of) a raised hand (D2:12)

gira.entry: képa dwíqle gírət mìya |  The stone has become scaled from the water

gisqa.gloss: one- to two-year old male goat

gista.entry: ʾo gista xaθəx Oh your poor sister (C3:3)

glola.gloss: circle. adj. (f. galolta, pl. galole) round

gnaya.entry: lɛ́le gnàyi |  It is not my fault; ʾína lɛ́wa mə́dre gnàyux |  But again it was not your fault (A1:25).

gnɛθət yoma.entry: gu-sáʾət ʾə́šta ʾaṣə́rta šáwwa gu-gnɛ́θət yòma, |  hóle θéle Čùxo |  At six or seven o’clock in the evening, at dusk, Čuxo came (A7:21).

gnuna.entry: θáyɛle qàša |  ʾu-sáṛa gnùnɛle |  The priest comes and ties the wedding band (B5:44)

goja.gloss: stock of tree; large root of a tree

goṛa.entry: (1) big (in size) | gilándi rába gòṛɛle |  A scythe is very big (B5:143); ʾotáxe gòṛe hawéwa |  Rooms were large (B10:51).; (2) great (in power or importance) ʾíθwa lìθwa |  biš-m-álaha góṛa čú-mdi lìθwa |  There was, there was not, there was nothing greater than God (opening formula of stories) (A30:1); ʾeða goṛa the great festival = Easter. Used as nominal: góṛət ʾAmedìya |  The chief of Amedia (A25:45).; (3) old (person) | ʾána xa-náša gòṛɛwən, |  wíra b-šə̀nne |  I am an old man, advanced in years (A8:43); naša goṛa b-šənne an elderly person; goṛət ʾumra advanced in age; xóna ʾo-góṛa the eldest brother (A12:17); Náze ʾɛ-gòṛta |  Naze, the eldest one (A25:16); kùllən, |  mən-yále zóre ʾu-hal-gòṛe |  All of us, from young children to old people (B16:4).

goriya.entry: hoyə́nwa gorìye |  Let me be his redeemer, let me die instead of him. Used in devotional expressions in combination with names of saints: Mar-Sàwa, |  goríyət xɛ̀le |  Saint Sawa, a sacrifice for his strength.

gota.entry: ʾasṛíwala b-qɛ́sa ʾu-m-áy-gota qɛ̀sa |  ʾu-m-áy-gota qɛ̀sa |  They would bind them to a stick, with a stick this side and a stick that side (B7:16); holá-ʾəθye tìwe, |  báxta tíwta l-àyya-gotət més, |  ʾu-gáwṛa tíwa l-ày-gota |  They came and sat down, the wife sitting on this side of the table and the husband sitting on the other side (A4:57); ṱ-ázət zɛ́nət gótə d-o-xaràya |  Go and stand by the side of the last one (A8:47); šqílɛle xa-šəndòxa |  ṭrípəlle l-gota-dìya |  He took a smooth stone and threw it at her (A30:37); kúlla ṣalɛ́wa gota-xtɛ̀θa |  They would all fall down (B5:43); ṃaḷɛ́wa qərṭála m-ay-gṓt tərnèy |  They would fill the pannier basket on both sides (B5:137); m-kúlla goyàθa |  on all sides (A8:48); kízle mxàya |  goyáθət sùsa, |  súsa la-jwìjle |  He tried to strike the sides of the horse, but the horse did not move (A28:33).

grawəzna.gloss: load of harvested rice carried on the back in a piece of cloth

gubbān.entry: har-gubbā̀n-ix wíðəlle |  We made it exactly according to a spirit-level (A17:20).

gučča.entry: maxə́nnux xa-gùčča |  I shall punch you.

guda.entry: gúda máre naθyàθɛle |  The wall has ears (A29:6).

guða.gloss: skin bag (for churning or carrying liquids)

gugiθa.entry: ða-gugíθa b-šáwwa boyàye. |  mòdile? |  rèša. |  A small stump of a tree with seven holes-What is it? A head (D1:17)

gullira.entry: grows on the mɛša and p̣aṛma trees; used for tanning (gmara).

gulpa.entry: píšəlla xákma gulpàne |  dáx d-an-t-ṭèra. |  She had acquired some wings like those of a bird (A8:76).

guniya.entry: made of flax, imported from towns. Sacks made in the villages out of animal hair are known as juwala.

gupta.entry: gupta mṭumarta cheesed buried in ground to mature

guṛuθa.entry: háwya bríxta guṛùθux |  May your bravery be blessed (= bravo!) (A24:21).

gušma.entry: lá-maxət gúšma ʾurə̀dxa |  Do not punch a needle (D2:59) → gučča

gwarta.entry: mò-hoyali gwárta-w? |  What good would marriage be to me? (A16:5)

gwina.gloss: boundary, side (of field, paddy field basin)
gwina.entry: marmíwa gwinánət məššàre |  They would build up the sides of the paddy field basins.

gyatta.gloss: finish at top of a wall on which the roof is laid; finishing at edge of woven material.

ġaləbuθa.entry: w-àti |  qa-dìyux |  xa-ġaləbúθa gòṛtɛle |  ʾən-bróni tàrəṣ |  It would be a big achievement on your part if my son is cured (A8:36).

ġðaðe.entry: bróni ʾu-brátux xə́zyela ġðàðe |  My son and your daughter saw each other (A4:26); ʾu-xíllən kúllən m-ġðàðe |  and we all ate together (A21:39); ʾu-ʾìtlən |  ʾəštá-maθwaθa qúrba l-ġðàðela |  We have six villages that are near to one another (B1:3); xa-xa-gáye ʾi-maxéwa tmanyà saʾə̀tte |  bar-ġðáðe t-là-klɛθa |  Sometimes, they played for eight hours continuously without stopping (B15:77).

ha.entry: hàyyo! |  hóla hà! |  šqúlla yalə̀xθa |  Come! Here it is! Take the handkerchief. (A4:18); ha-šqùl |  Here, take (them) (A6:3).

habriya.entry: šəṭro marθət habriya the beautiful woman who possesses the headscarf (C2:1)

hade.entry: yóma hádele zrìqa |  The sun has just now risen (A26:37); yále zóre háde bə̀rye |  young children just born (A8:10); ʾána hàden pláṭa |  I am just now coming out (A23:11). hade m-hade as just now, once again: hade-m-háde píšlən xawràne |  We became friends once again (B5:132); zìla |  mtugə̀brəlla |  háde m-hàde-w |  They went and put it in order once again (A23:24).

hadəx.gloss: thus; like that; the same; so much.
hadəx.entry: (1) thus, like that | dax-ṱ-ile xə́zyəlla θàya, |  hádəx ṣràxa-w |  xumθàne, |  Čúxo rìqɛle |  When he saw them coming, shouting like this and angry, Čuxo ran away (A7:16); páyəšwa ʾax-xàlwa, |  brìza hádəx |  It would become like curds, dry, (it was) like that (B7:22).; (2) the same | dártət-yoma zílla wídla hàdəx |  The next day she went and did the same (A18:3); xàrθa, |  pàlṭeti |  ʾap-ʾaṣə́rta hàdəx |  Then, you go out, and in the evening (do) the same (A22:23); har-hádəx ʾŭ́mur Már Qiyòma |  The age of Mar Qiyoma is the same (B1:7).; (3) Making temporal intervals in narrative: šə́ryela gu-d-ɛ́ ʾotél ʾo-yòma-w |  píšela hàdəx, |  ʾaṣə́rta θìθɛla |  bắyi ṱ-áxli xa-ràmša |  They put up in the hotel that day and remained like that (until) the evening came and they wanted to eat dinner (A2:2); xa-béna wítɛla hádəx b-lɛ̀le |  mə́xyɛle taq-taq-táq l-tằra |  Then, at night, there was a knock at the door (A23:26); bar-hàdəx, |  y-aθɛ́wa mdarɛ̀wale |  qa-t-lá-hawa píše šə̀xte |  Then they would come and winnow it (B5:86); hádəx ʾáp-ati ʾə̀θyət |  Meanwhile you also came (A2:9).; (4) so much | ʾo-xáwri hádəx gabbàra, |  xázəx wírre gawàye |  We saw my friend, who was such a huge man, go inside (B15:58); hàdəx-iwa xóš-naša |  hàdəx-iwa spày |  He was such a good man, he was so good (A4:31).

hāl.entry: hā́l hawā́l ʾàtxɛla |  The situation is like this (A8:35); hā́l ʾu-hawā́l hátxa xzèli |  I saw such-and-such things (A4:7); hā́l-u qə́ṣṣət hàtxɛla |  The situation is like this (A12:42); ʾána háli m-halɛ̀xu |  I shall live like you (A14:97); líθ wíya čù-məndi, |  genáwe hàle? |  Has anything happened? Thieves or the like? (A29:22); ṱ-ázən máθyən xáčča štɛ̀θa, |  màzza, |  məndi-hàle |  I shall go and bring some drink, nibbles, and the like (A17:25); míla l-hàlux! |  Confound you! (literally: Blue on your condition!) (A23:10).

hala.entry: used before a negative copula or negative existential particle: ʾìna |  núrət xàle |  ṱ-íwa síqa l-tàma |  gu-zòma |  hála lɛ̀le č̣ə́mya |  The fire in the summer house of his maternal uncle, where he was making for, had still not gone out (A25:40); ʾáwwa nàša |  hála lìtwale |  This man still did not yet have (a son) (A8:5).

halwasna.entry: It grows on a sunniθa tree

ham.entry: (1) also | ʾap-m-d-áni y-óði muràbba, |  yáʿni ham-mən-sparə̀gle |  They make jam also from these, that is also from quinces (B5:219).; (2) even | in conditional constructions: hám-ʾən yawə́tli zùze, |  lè-y-aθən |  Even if you give me money, I shall not come.; (3) again | ham-zílɛle kə́sle dìye |  He went again to him (A25:25); ham-mṣawòre ʾə́lle díye |  He curses him again (A17:3).

hămanta.entry: ʾíða hămànta |  a trusted hand (a deposit made by the groom’s family to the bride’s family as a token of securing the betrothal) (B5:5); hămántət bɛ̀θa |  trust in the family (B5:44).

ḥaqq.entry: kəmɛ́le ḥàqqe? |  What is its price?| ʾáxni šáqləx ḥáqqət ʾəjàra mə́nne díye |  We shall receive wages from him (A14:15); ʾu-la-ḥáqqət kàrmi lɛle-yáwa |  nor does he pay the price of the orchard (A17:30).

ḥaqquθa.entry: ʾu-haqquθɛ́xu le-y-ṭàlqa |  Your right will not be lost (A8:88); ʾína ʾítli ḥaqqùθi |  but I (must) have my fee (A27:19); ṱ-ázən ṭắyən báθər ḥaqqùθa |  ʾu-na-ḥaqqùθa |  I shall go and search for what is lawful and what is unlawful (A15:5); xále díye t-ḥaqqùθa |  His real uncle (A23:28).

har.gloss: always; again; still; as soon as; directly; just, only; the same; surely (§15.11.).
har.entry: (1) always, constantly | har-bxàya-wawa |  They were constantly continued crying (A25:5); ʾu-ʾáti har-háwət baràye |  ʾu-sáprət ku-t-áθe làxxa |  You be outside all the time and wait for whoever comes here (A22:23); har-blígət b-kàsux |  You are always busy with your stomach (A23:10).; (2) again | yómət ṭḷàθa |  har-ṣlèla |  On the third day she went down again (A22:18).; (3) still | Temporal persistence: ʾu-dəbbóre hár-hola qam-tắrət bòya |  The hornets were still before the door of the hole (A20:9); har-xáθe ʾi-bằyela |  He still loves his sister (A18:16); ʾáy har-là-yawəlla |  It still does not give it back (A34:4); hal-lɛle < har-lɛle: hal-lɛ̀la gláya |  She (the mother) still does not reveal (the truth) (A38:6). Logically unexpected: kəmə̀t ṱ-árqena |  tópe har-ṭapyàli |  However much I run, a gun will still reach me (B9:3).; (4) as soon as | har-ðìlɛxu príqlən mən-ṭúra, |  dɛ́rən tòpe, |  kút-xa maxèla |  xánjər dìye, |  ʾo-ṱ-íle qáme díye qaṭə̀lle |  As soon as you know that we have finished (coming over) the mountain, I shall fire a gun and everyone will strike with his dagger and kill the man in front of him (B19:6); har-qítla bìyux, |  qaṭlílux ṱ-axlìlux |  As soon as they hit you, they will kill you and eat you (A22:39).; (5) directly | har-ʾə́θyɛle mən-ṭúra réša-reša d-o-gàre |  He came straight from the mountain onto the roof (A23:14).; (6) just, only | har-ʾàna hon-zlíma |  Only I am wronged (A13:5); lá har-ʾáxni zlìme |  Not only we are wronged (A13:16); har-ʾàwwɛle |  He is alone (A17:16); har-ʾàti |  you yourself (and nobody else) (A27:6); hár-xa xále dìyele |  It is his one and only uncle (A28:11). Narrowing the extent of an action: ʾína bróna lɛ̀la xíltəlle. |  har-nobáltəlle muttɛ́θəlle mattòye. |  She did not eat the boy. She just took him and put him down. (A19:7); ʾána har-ṣálən mðìta |  mɛ́θən ʾixàla |  ʾu-ʾàθena |  I’ll just go down to the town to bring food and come back (A26:30).; (7) the same | in combination with demonstratives: hàr ʾo-yóma on the same day (A25:4).; (8) surely, indeed | ʾáxni har-xònən-it |  You are indeed our brother (A39:12); ʾay-xá-yoma har-t-yằða |  ṱ-íle míθa brònən |  She will surely know one day that our son is dead (A4:39)

harmiya.entry: harmiyət čeri autumn pear; harmiyət qɛṭa summer pear

hašya.entry: ʾašitnàye |  qəm-mpalṭíla ʾáwwa šálət qðàla, |  hàšya |  The people from Ashitha produced the neck shawl, (made of) lace (B10:50); zaqrə́xwa hàšye, |  laqṭə̀xwa |  We would weave works of lace and embroider them (B10:85); xmaṭət hašya needle for sewing lace.

hašya.2.gloss: herb put in jajək and cheese (like chive)

hatta.entry: hátta Gozáli b-gáne mšudrə́tle lɛ̀n θíθa |  Even (when) you sent Gozali himself, I did not come (A8:94); hat-yəmméy wírən ṭàlba |  I entered attacking even their mother (A12:18); hátta mɛxólta b-kàwe dárəx ʾəlle-díye |  We even give food to it through the window (A12:62).

hatxa.entry: si-hátxa múrgən ṭla-màlka |  Go, say thus to the king (A17:30); hàtxɛla qə́ṣṣət |  The story is like this (A13:5); háyyo hátxa hátxa mə̀nnux! |  Come on you so-and-so! (curse) (A28:21). Adverb: mjunəgníla hàtxa |  She shook them like this (A4:15); wíðɛle hó hátxa ʾax-də̀bba |  He behaved just like a bear (B18:5). Governing a nominal: hátxa mə̀ndi |  such a thing (A14:6); čú-bena lat-ṭlíbta hátxa məndiyáne díya hot-ṭlàba! |  You have never requested such things are you are requesting now (A26:45). Governing an adjective: ʾíman ṱ-íle xə̀zyəlla, |  hátxa šəṭránta-w šapìrta, |  ʾay-ṣrìxla |  When he saw her, so beautiful and good-looking, she screamed (A4:4). Expressing approximation: ʾaṣə̀rta |  sáʾət ʾə́šta ʾàtxa |  in the evening, around six o’clock (B15:43). End of discourse unit: xíšɛle l-bɛ̀θa |  lɛ́le-hiwa ʾàtxa |  He did not give (the money) and that was that (A1:9).

havrəkka.entry: tre yalone havrəkke šarreley rəš-mamməkke two rival children are fighting on the breasts (C2:39).

hawar.entry: haware! Help!; hàwarila |  Help! (A32:21); hàwər-ila |  What a calamity! (A7:10); píštɛla háwar gu-màθa |  There was a cry of alarm in the village (B5:162); draya hawar/hawər to call in anguish, call for help: šúryɛle mxáya gu-réše dráya hàwər |  He began beating his head yelling in anguish (A7:10); ʾáp-xa la-mṣèle |  θéle mṭéle hawàrən |  Nobody could come to help us (B15:41).

hawd.entry: qumte rixana t-hawdi His figure was (that of) a basil in my flower-bed (C2:65)

hawna.entry: mɛθə̀nne háwni |  I shall try to work it out (literally: I shall bring my intelligence) (A26:36).

hawše.entry: constructed with wicker fencing (gədla), usually in the mountains, where the sheep spend the night: ʾíθ ḥáwše t-ṭùra, |  mturáṣta xa-dúkθa gu-ṭùra, |  képe y-áwa zə̀dyəlla, |  murə́xməlla qa-t-ʾə́rwe dàwṛi táma |  There is a mountain sheep-fold, a place made in the mountains, in which they have removed the stones and which they have made suitable for the sheep to dwell in.

hazər.entry: hazər qa-štaya ready for drinking; ʾánna məndiyáne ṱ-it-ṭlábəlla kúlla hàzərila |  All the things that you request are ready (A8:38); simàrxa |  wíðtɛla gána hàzər |  The simarxa bird prepared herself (A27:13).

he.entry: maṣítu mšadrítula kə̀sli? |  mə́ra hè |  He said ‘Can you send her to me?’ They said ‘Yes’ (A4:13).

hedi hedi.entry: ʾáy hédi-hedi qìmla |  She got up slowly (A20:5); hédi hédi bašə́lwa ʾixàla |  The food cooked slowly (B10:87)

hemza.gloss: edible herb with pungent root and white sap

heš.entry: (1) still | héš xúya xùyɛle |  It is still very dark (A30:36); ʾáy heš-hóla gu-gòma |  She is still in the basement stable (A18:22). As an intensifier of a comparative: heš-bìš qam-xóna díya qímtɛla |  She rose still earlier than her brother (A8:69); b-qáryən ʾu-hèš-biš záwda |  I shall call yet louder (A8:72).; (2) heš + negator = not yet | heš-lɛ́le làxxa |  He is not here yet; heš-lɛ́le ʾə̀θya |  He has not come yet; š-lɛ́wa mšúrya xála gə̀lla |  It had not yet started to eat grass (B5:175); qəm-dári ʾan-dáwwe heš-t-là bráza |  They have poured out the dawwe while it is not yet dry (B14:1).; (3) la + heš (generally contracted to leš, lɛš, laš, ləš) = no longer | léš-ʾaθəx hayorə̀xlux |  We shall no longer come to help you (A48:6); leš faydáləx qáṭlət gànəx |  It will no longer be of any use to you to kill yourself (A38:16); ʾáqlət susɛ́xu ʾən-píšla kèpa, |  léš maṣítu jawjìtu |  If the legs of your horses have become stone, you will no longer be able to move (A8:28); léš-ile gu-bɛ̀θa |  He is no longer in the house; lɛ́š-in xzàya |  I can no longer see (A24:2).

hewən.entry: ʾáyya ṱók̭e b-áwwa héwən, m-ɛ̀ka ṱók̭e díya?! |  Is this a ṱok̭e bird in this season? Where has a ṱok̭e bird come from at this time? (A30:36); hewənət xzada the harvest season; qč̣ipewəx mqorəč̣pewəx |  t-la-b-hewən ʾu-t-la măjalən |  We are cut down and harvested not in the season nor in our time (for cutting) (A51:8); fa-y-áθe tàlga, |  ʾu-náše mšɛ́ri b-hèwaney |  maṣlɛ́wa karàθa |  (When) the snow came, people would start bringing down loads (of leaves) as they needed them (literally: in their season) (B5:120); hèwənile |  Is is time (to take the honeycomb from the hive) (B5:177); héwən-t gàre |  the season of (sleeping on) the roof (B10:59).

hezara.gloss: wooden beam used to lock a door

hezuke.entry: y-ázi y-óði hèzuke |  They go and swing (on a swing) (B6:6)

hɛrike.entry: made in preparation for cultivation of rice: tré-yomaθa ṭḷàθa, |  maštɛ̀wala |  qá-t xáčča pɛ́šawa rakìxta. |  ... ʾáwwa y-amrə́xxe wáða hɛrìke |  Three or four days beforehand, they would irrigate it so that it would become quite soft. ... We call this making ‘soft mud beds’ (B5:76).

həlma.entry: bắyən mə̀nnux |  hə́lma t-yáwət b-rèši |  I want you to blow on me (A25:12); hóla susăwàθa |  jə̀mye b-réše díye |  wáða hə̀lma |  b-réše dìye |  The horses were gathered over him, blowing onto him (A25:13).

hənd.entry: hə́nd ṃaḷèwa |  It was just enough (B10:6). Before the 3fs. copula (hənṱ-ila) in temporal expressions: hənṱ-ila xə́zyəlla gane-díye tráb gu-ʾùrxa |  All of a sudden (literally: it is a little) he found himself-bang-on a road (A8:40); hə́nṱ-ila ṱ-àθe |  He will come very soon; hə́nṱ-ila rzígli m-šùla |  I shall be finished with work very soon.

hənna.entry: (1) thing | used as filler: ʾána háwən šḗx d-áyya hə̀nna |  I am the sheikh of this thing (i.e. tribe) (A7:7).; (2) trifle, small amount | used as a clausal conjunction: hə́n-ṱ-ile ṱ-àθe |  He will come in a jiffy (= He is about to come); hə́n-ṱ-iwən t-rázgən |  I shall finish in a jiffy (= I am about to finish); hə́n-ṱ-ile xə́zyəlla gane-díye tráb gu-ʾùrxa |  In a trifle (= suddenly) he found himself on a road (A8:40).

həšše.entry: hóle zíla m-hə́šše dìye |  He has lost his senses; ʾáw l-hə́šše dìyele |  He is conscious.

həšyər.entry: wi-hə̀šyər! Be careful!; háwət hə́šyər t-là-ʾaθi ʾə́llux |  Be careful they do not accost you (A22:26); háwət hə́šyər ʾína ʾáyya sústa là marpə́tla |  Be careful not to let that horse go (A12:29); daréle gu-yáma hə̀šyər |  He put it in the sea carefully (A12:30).

hič.entry: ʾíθwa-w lìθwa |  bíš m-álaha gòṛa |  líθwa gòṛa |  hič-nàša |  There was and there was not, there was no man greater than God (opening formula of a story) (A8:2).

hiwi.entry: ʾitli hiwi ṱ-aθən I hope to come; ʾítli híwi ṱ-áwət sáx ʾu-sălaməttùθa |  I hope you will be fine and in good health; ʾo-t-páyəš b-híwi-t nàše |  míθɛle mən-bərmàše |  He who relies on other people is dead by the evening (D2:28); žɛ́re Fàrxo |  ṱ-íwən ʾána b-hìwi díya |  Poor (me), Farxo, who am waiting in hope for her (A25:18); ʾáyya muttáwtəlla híwət bàbi |  She had abandoned hope regarding my father (B9:11); káze wáða hìwi mə́nne |  ʾána xulàmux |  He tried to beg him (saying) ‘I am your servant’ (A29:33).

ho.entry: hó ʾan-ṭḷá gerə-qə̀šta |  Here are the three arrows of a bow (A12:46); ho-θèli |  Look I have come (A12:66); ho-də́ryənna gáni ʾup-ʾána gu-mìya |  See I threw myself into the water (B15:34).

hodəx.entry: píðɛle hòdəx |  He passed further on (A41:4); xáčča xéna biš-hódəx a little further on (A7:22); xáčča bìš hódəx mənna-díya |  a little further along from them (A12:47); m-táma hódəx ṱ-ázət máṭət xa-nèra |  From here onwards is the valley of the ants (A14:50); m-táma hòdəx |  ʾáxtu ʾu-gʸanɛ̀xu |  From then onwards you are by yourselves (A8:27); ʾána ʾáwwa ʾíle bɛ̀θi |  m-díya hòdəx |  This is my house from now on (B5:41); l-ay-gōt-hòdəx t-šaqíθa |  on the farther side of the channel (A9:1); ʾána bi-zóda m-hódəx là-maṣən ʾoðə́nnux |  čù məndí |  I cannot do anything more for you (A8:44). mod. yonder | m-támma hódəx ṭùra ʾáθṛə d-ánna dèwele |  From here to yonder mountain is the land of the wolves (A14:48).

hosa.entry: bréla hòsa |  Panic broke out (C7:8); músqəlle dáwla-w zòrna-w |  hósa ʾu-gargàrta |  They brought him up (with) drum and pipe, and with clamour and shouting (A4:25).

hotxa.entry: mɛ́θət tə́nna m-ày-gota, |  ṱ-ázi dabáše hòtxa |  You put smoke on this side and the bees will go aside (B14:13).

hudxa.entry: ʾána m-axxa-húdxa lɛ̀-y-azən |  I shall not go beyond here (A12:23)

huta.entry: ʾáwwa náša hùtɛle |  This man (eats like) a whale, he is greedy; šə́mša qəm-băléla ḥùta |  a whale has swallowed the sun (i.e. it is eclipsed).

ḥajətta.entry: me-zome ṣlela b-hajjəttət maše She came down from his summer pastures with the excuse of (fetching) black beans (C6:1); jawə́tta ʾíla hájət šùla |  The chopper is a work tool.

ḥajjiyuθa.entry: ʾən-lá zɛrə́nna Qŭ̀dus, |  lɛ̀la qbílta ḥajjiyúθi |  If I do not visit Jerusalem, my pilgrimage is not accepted (A2:1).

ḥălāl.entry: háwya halā̀l ṭlálux |  Let her be permitted to you (A12:34); ʾu-hoya ḥalalta ṭlala and let it be permitted for her (C1:11).

ḥammam.entry: ʾaw-l-ḥàmmam sáxe |  He washes in the bathroom (A21:17)

ḥărām.entry: ḥărā́m-ile gáwṛa ʾə̀lli |  šúq mən-dìyux |  Any man is forbidden to me except you (A12:35); n.pl. hăramāt | ʾu-zílle hăramā̀t |  It was sold for nothing (A22:9).

ḥaṣəl.entry: in phrase wa-l-ḥaṣəl (A.) and in sum.

jabla.gloss: mud and straw mix acting as cement in the construction of houses

jajək.gloss: yoghurt mixed with water (dawwe) and the herbs sərmo, hašya, purəpxina or bizər

jalda.entry: qəm-maxèle |  ʾəṣrà-jalde |  He struck him ten strokes (A30:14).

jalde.entry: y-awə́ðle jàlde |  He does it quickly; lwíša júlle hátxa jálde jàlde |  He put on his clothes very quickly (A4:55); šqilíle jal-jàlde |  He quickly took them (A15:2); kut-sámqa jàlde, |  šaqlàla |  She takes out whichever one (flat bread) is brown soonest (B5:102); kút maṭéwa qamáya jàldəlle |  mɛθèwale |  Whoever was the quickest and reached it first would bring it back (B5:154); ʾána θéli jàlde |  I am early; qedamta jalde early in the morning. m-jalde recently; a long while ago | m-jàldela ʾə́θye They have come recently; ʾáyya lɛ̀wa rába m-jálde, |  bálki ṱ-àwya |  ʾə́mma-w xámši šə́nne hàtxa |  This was not very recently, perhaps it was something like a hundred and fifty years ago (B4:17); ʾaw-bə́nyɛle m-jálde ʾatìqa |  It was built in very ancient times (B14:2).

jalla nune.entry: It has a long beak (naqruza rixa) and comes to the region in winter

jallada.entry: bába díya hóle mùtta |  jallàde |  Her father has appointed executioners (A25:32).

jaməkka.entry: mḥuṣə́lla jamə̀kke |  She gave birth to twins (A8:6)

jănaza.entry: hadíya gáwṛəx píša jănàzɛle |  Your husband is now dead (A10:13).

jaqsi.entry: ʾu-síqɛle gu-d-ó sàrga |  mtúrṣa l-an-jaqsìye |  t-mðìta |  He went up onto the saddle, which was made by the town craftsmen (A8:52); sɛ́pe díye ... qəm-nablále kəs-jàqši |  She took his sword to a craftsman (A52:11)

jareta.gloss: food for journey or work, food bag
jareta.entry: mattə́nnux jarréta lə́xma zeðàye |  I shall provide you with a food-box of pitta breads (A30:5); də-mjămə́xlən jarrèta |  Let us put together a food bag for ourselves (A30:41).

jarge.entry: ʾUsman mxurxile jarge He burnt the viscera of Usman (C7:10)

jăwāb.entry: ṱ-awéləx jăwā́b ʾàti |  You will have an answer (A8:74); ʾɛ́-ga xárθa θéle xa-jăwāb qa-màlka |  Then, in the end, a report came to the king (A8:5); yíwɛle jăwába ṭla-yàla |  He conveyed a message to the young man (A21:33).

jəlja.gloss: slice of meat that is hung in the sun to dry
jəlja.entry: When such slices dry, they are called qadida and stored in a bag known as mziða.

jənjara.entry: npílewəx gu-jəngàra |  We fell on hard times; jənjarət sətwa the hardship of the winter

jiðoqe.entry: eaten as a dish, stuffed and cooked

jubarrək.gloss: mite that eats rice and flour

jŭda.entry: ʾáwwa glās máttule jŭ̀da |  Put this glass aside; ʾánna məndiyáne jŭ̀dela |  These things are different.

judala.entry: ʾáni ʾu-qáša Sɛ́rgun wírra b-judàla |  These people and the priest Sargun entered into an argument (B1:17).

julla.entry: hóle də́rya jùlla b-réša |  He put a cloth over them (A25:48). julle n.pl. clothes | julle ṭiyariyana Ṭiyare style clothes (festive clothes worn by the groom at a wedding B10:33); kúlley júlle díye y-áwa nčìle |  All his clothes were ragged (B16:10); diya-mɛ́θu júlli malušùla |  Now bring my clothes and put them on (me) (A4:20); xamšá-mma bnàθa |  kúlla lwíše júllət ʾùrze |  five hundred girls, all wearing men’s clothes (A25:76).

jurjēt.entry: jurjēt zərqəf decorated fabric , jurjēt sada fabric without decorations

juwala.entry: local produce made of goat’s hair (seṛət ʾərwət kome), as opposed to the type of sack know as guniya, which is manufactured outside the villages

juwiθa.gloss: pot that is buried in the ground to make jajək
juwiθa.entry: It is covered with a fig leaf (ṭarpət tena) and a small piece of fabric (čəngərta).

jvoṭa.entry: kawsa jvoṭa straight hair (anton. kawsa kərtana curly hair), qɛse jvoṭe straight sticks

jwanqa.entry: ʾa-parṣópa díyux hátxa jwànqa |  This face of yours, which is so handsome (A8:41)

ka.entry: dáx mṣéle ʾáyya bráta qəm-ʾawə́dla b-pəlxánət bɛ̀θa, |  ʾu-ká-t brátət màlka |  ʾu-lípta har-dmàxa-w xála |  How could he have made this girl a hard-working housewife, while (she is) the daughter of the king and is used to only sleeping and eating (A21:32); mbúrxəllən l-ġðàðe |  ka-xóna ʾu-xàθa, |  lá ka-gáwṛa-w bàxta |  They have wed us together while (we are) brother and sister, and not while (we are) husband and wife (A16:8).

kălama.gloss: long thorn of parzena or jwanna tree

kalba.entry: kálba brət-kálba dog son of a dog! (A6:12); kálbe bərt-kàlbe |  dogs sons of dogs! (A7:15).

kalle.entry: kállət gamèše |  a herd of buffaloes (A32:17)

kămaxa.gloss: pelvis bone; haunch of an animal

kanda.entry: qaṣrux banyanne l-kanda I shall build your palace on a cliff top (C3:10)

kanuna.gloss: stones used for cooking; fireplace, hearth
kanuna.entry: This is either open or enclosed by a clay cover to trap the heat. It is located in house or outhouse (ṣopiθa)

kapora.entry: 1. infidel, scoundrel | ʾáwwa kapòrɛle. |  ʾána ʾəṣrà-jalde məxyə́lli. |  He is a scoundrel. He beat me with ten strokes. (A30:15); 2. awful (weather) | ʾɛ́we ʾən-θéla m-la-Zàwa, |  ṱ-áθe xa-yóma ṭàwa. |  ʾən-ʾɛ́we θéla m-Xawòra, |  ṱ-áθe xa-yóma kapòra. |  If the clouds come from the side of the Zab (i.e. the East), a good day will come. If the clouds come from the Khabur (i.e. the West), an awful day will come (D2:16).

kār.entry: ʾíθwa kə́ma gəllále palṭíwa mən-d-ò-rəzza, |  qá-t la-ʾoðíwa kɛ̄̀r |  there were several plants that they took out of the rice, so that they did not have an effect (B5:78)

karaxa.entry: He was concerned principally with regulating the flow of water in water channels (šaqyaθa). → karxa

karba.entry: ʾána-ži m-kɛ́rbi ʾə́θyən ʾá-kθɛθa múttənna rəš-núra ʾu-xìlənna |  I, out of my anger, came and put the chicken on the fire and ate it (A2:11).

kareza.gloss: deep channel for bringing subterranean water to the surface or conducting a spring from the hills to the plain

karrəkka.2.entry: tuθe karrəkke unripe mulberries; tuθta karrəkθa an unripe mulberry

karta.gloss: load of wood (tied together with rope)
karta.entry: kút-yum ʾazáwa l-ṭúra maθyáwa ða-kɛ́rta qɛ́sa l-xáṣa dìya |  Everyday she would go to the mountains and bring a load of wood on her back (A10:6); mattúla kàrte |  He lays down his load (A15:3).

karxa.entry: This word is not generally used in Barwar (where məššara is the normal term for this), but its derivative karaxa irrigation administrator is widely current.

kašxa.entry: ʾína huðáya lwíša kášxa-w júlle xàθe |  Behold the Jew was wearing a smart suit and new clothes (A6:6)

kata.gloss: leaf sprouting on felled tree or severed branch

k̭avərra.gloss: one- to two-year old male sheep

k̭avərta.gloss: one- to two-year old female sheep

kawe.gloss: small window without glass; small aperture; small hole in the wall of a church in which burning wicks (punde) are placed
kawe.entry: ʾíθwa xa-kàwe |  l-gàre |  There was a window in the roof (A10:4); kawət tăra a small hole in a door. In winter the breezes were stopped blowing through such windows in houses by placing a woolen cloth (jullət ʾamṛa) in the hole.

k̭awəlla.entry: ma-píštət k̭awə̀lla! |  How you have become a ruin! (A16:18).

kawta.entry: xa-káwtət ʾə̀rwe |  a flock of sheep (A32:14).

kawuθra.entry: b-óma xéna ʾáθeti ṭla-kawùθra |  The day after tomorrow come to lunch (A22:14); kawúθrux brìxta |  Good afternoon.

k̭ēm.entry: k̭ēm naše a few people; k̭ḕm baxtáθa a few women (B10:22); xa-k̭ḗm y-óði hàtxa |  A few do this; gə́lla k̭ḕm hawéwa |  Grass was scarce. With the comparative particle biš: bálki bíš-k̭ēm mən-ʾəštà-mma šə́nnela |  Perhaps it is less than six-hundred years old (B6:31).

kerapso.entry: pungent to the taste, eaten crushed and mixed with red sumac berries (smoqe)

kəzma.gloss: wooden prop supporting vine in a vineyard

kežurta.gloss: fine pieces of wood put on roof
kežurta.entry: Roofs were constructed with several layers in the following order: qaryaθa (large beams), nire/qarše (slats), kežurta (fine wooden pieces), ṭarpa (leaves), jabla (cement), ʾupra (clay), ʾupra xwara (white clay), sərsərra (powdered white clay)

kɛla.entry: b-ó-kɛla pɛ́šət kìla |  You will be measured by the same measure (A41:6).

kɛra.entry: ʾaw-wíðəlla kɛ́re dìye |  He prepared himself for a fight (A18:17); wúdla kɛ̀rux! |  Be prepared for a fight!

kəčkaje.entry: These were mainly eaten during Lent

kēf.entry: kèfuxila |  It is up to you, do as you please; har-m-kèfəx? |  Is that really your wish (B9:13); dáx-ile kèfux? |  How are you doing? (A22:12); ʾáwwa θéle kèfe |  He became happy (A22:18); mábsəm ʾu-ṭáre kḕf |  He will enjoy himself and have a good time (A2:8); málla múttəlle réše dmìxa, |  ṭlìya, |  kéfe basìmta |  The mullah lay down his head, lay down and slept contented (A6:5); lɛ́la maxrówəlla kèfa |  They do not disturb her (A21:9); dawə́qle xmára b-íðe qa-t-lá-ʾazəl kéfe dìye |  He holds the ass by his hand so that it does not walk about freely; mqáwlət goràtle, |  t-yálla jùlla. |  ʾən-là, |  har-t-yálla júlləx b-kèfəx |  If you promise to marry him, he will give back the clothes. If not, he will still give you the clothes, if you want them (A14:83); klɛ̀! |  ʿala-kèfəx! |  Wait! calm down! (A4:19).

kəma.gloss: how many/much? some, several; so much/many; however much, as much as; when; as for (§14.9.9., §19.3.5.)
kəma.entry: (1) how many? how much? (interrogative) | ʾína kəmà-gaye zíllux ʾu-šqíllux ʾáyya? |  How many times have you gone and taken it? (B15:90); ʾawwa ʾaskaríya dìye |  ṭlà-kəma dánɛla? |  For what time is this army of his for? Used independently: kəmà t-yátli? |  How much will you give me? (A24:5). Used predicatively: sáʾət kəmɛ̀la? |  The time is how much? (= What time is it?) (A26:27). Adverb: kəmà zonə́tle? |  For how much will you buy him? (A24:23).; (2) some, several | kə́ma gàye |  several times (B9:18); y-oráwa kə́ma yàrxe |  Several months passed (B5:18).; (3) so much, so many (exclamatory) | ʾána kəmà dána ṱ-in-mṣalóye ṭla-márya ʾàlaha |  ta-t-yawə́lli ʾə̀mma dáwe |  I was praying to the Lord God so many times to give me a hundred gold coins (A6:10); kəma-basìmtɛla ʾixála! |  The food is so delicious! (A21:31). Adverb: baxtáθa kə́ma zădíwa mən-xuwwàwe! |  The women feared snakes so much! (B5:78). Governing a clause (usually abbreviated to ma): ʾánna ma-ṱ-íla xmíle b-ġðàðe! |  How happy they were together! (A4:50); ʾu-ṭə̀lyela |  ma-t-wáwa kčìxe |  They slept, so tired were they (A14:43).; (4) however much, as much as (governing a clause) | kəmə̀t ṱ-árqena |  tópe har-ṭapyàli |  However much I run, a gun will still reach me (B9:3); xúl kəma-t-bằyət |  Eat as much as you want (B15:56).; (5) when | ma-t-wéwa brōn-málka qə́ryəlle ʾo-kθàwa, |  mə́re spày! |  When the son of the king had read the letter, he said ‘Good!’ (A11:18).; (6) as for | kəmá ṱ-íle Rùstam, |  ʾáw mbaqórəlle Tătár-i Slemán-i Sə̀ndi |  As for Rustam, he asked for Tătar-i Sleman-i Səndi (A28:24).

kəndala.entry: ṣále kəndàla |  He goes down the slope (A28:19); táwre masóqəlla b-o-kəndàla |  He took the oxen up the slope (A30:9); ṱ-árqən b-o-kəndála hár qaṭlìli |  If I run down the slope, they will kill me (B9:4).

kəppəkθa.gloss: arch on the bottom of the foot (between heel and toes)

kepta.entry: (1) small stone | used to refer to the small stone that is heated in the fire and thrown in the snow as a game played in the celebrations at the end of the winter month of March).; (2) bullet, lead head of the bullet cartridge | dréli tópe ʾu-képta la-qìtla |  I fired the gun but the bullet did not hit (its mark); keptət pišanga head of the bullet cartridge.

kərkəroka.entry: kərkərokət qðala the adam’s apple of the neck

kərra.gloss: sheep or goat with short ears, crop-eared

kərsəlle.gloss: dung of horses asses and mules (sing. kursəlta a piece of dung)

kərtana.entry: kawsa kərtana (anton. kawsa jvoṭa straight hair).

kəsənθa.entry: max-kəsə́nθət dàwhɛla |  She is like a golden jewel.

kəštəvana.gloss: cross piece of wood in the frame of a bed (taxta) made of willow (xorta)

k̭ətta.entry: zawge ʾu-k̭ətte even and odd numbers. mod. odd | k̭ətte dukane in the odd place, in a few places; kúṱ-ila k̭ə́tte k̭ə́tte laqṭə̀tla |  Whatever is separate (fruits) you pick.

kima.entry: mbáqər kíma-w gabbàre |  ask the Pleiades and Orion (A38:12); ṱ-asqa čima-w gabbare Pleiades and Orion will rise (C2:3).

kizəkka.entry: b-lɛ́le rúmxe díye hóla mxáya kizə̀kke |  In the night his spear was giving off sparks (A12:9).

klama.gloss: wooden collar of ox; sacking tied over mouth of ox to prevent it from eating corn during threshing (dwara)

kliča.entry: šaqòla |  kúlle klìča |  a shank completely stripped of its meat (A30:30); ʾáyya dúkθe díye hátxa klíčta This part of him was scratched (B9:25).

klila.gloss: crown, coronet; coronet decorations on clothes
klila.entry: ma-yəmmux ʾazla klile Oh your mother spins crowns (A50:15)

koč̭a.gloss: hornless (goat/sheep); type of wheat without hairs (dasiye)

koləkθa.gloss: chicken coop; wooden chamber of a patridge trap buried in the ground; shooting hut (used when hunting patridges)

koma.entry: xáʾa lwíša kòma |  somebody dressed in black (A12:5).

kopa.entry: ʾəθyewəx kope kope qam-məṭra ʾu-qam dalope We have come bending down in rain and drizzle (C1:14). adv. below | náše ʾíwa kòpa |  kùlla, |  ʾu-ʾáwwa gárewa ràma |  The people were all below and he (the groom) was high up on the roof (B5:42)

kore.entry: This is narrower than a čale. Cheese and jajək are buried in a kore. gðaltət kore, ṭawaltət kore wrestling of the hole, game of the hole. One of the wrestlers has a foot in a hole. If the opponent pushes him over and his foot comes out of the hole, he loses the game.

kosa.entry: ʾən-lá doqə́tle də́qnux b-ìðux, |  la-ʾámrət qa-xáwrux kòsa |  If you cannot hold your own beard in your hand, do not call your friend beardless (D2:54).

kosta.gloss: pen for young lambs in basement stable

kotăla.gloss: raised tank attached to a water-mill which fills with water from a channel and releases water flow at a high pressure to drive the mill.
kotăla.entry: This structure was necessary when the water did not come from a natural height and did not have natural pressure.

koza.gloss: sheltered place for pasturing in inclement weather in Winter and Spring

krehət.entry: ʾƎ́šwuṭ rába krḕt-iwa gu-ʾàθṛa |  (The month of) February was very bad in our land (B5:152); ʾap-ʾƎ̀šwuṭ krèhət y-áwe |  (The month of) February is also bad (B5:197).

krihe.entry: rúšma t-krìhe |  the sign of the suffering ones (made to an infant at baptism) (B6:36)

kul.entry: (1) every | kúl-naša every person (B6:35); kúl-məndi everything (B10:64); kúl-xa suràya every Christian (B6:1); ku-bɛ́θa every house (B7:7); kul-náše tre-ṭḷá-yomane šatìwa |  Everybody would drink and eat for two or three days (B15:64).; (2) all, all of | kúlla náše all the people (B10:88); míye díye kúlla all its water (B6:42); ʾáni kùlla all of them (B7:17); kúlla tunìθa all of the story (A29:12); kúlla Bɛ̀rwər all of Barwar (B10:100); ʾo-bɛ́θa kúlla all of that family (B5:21); ʾixála kúlle all of the food (B6:5). Used independently: zadáwale kúlla m-gàre |  They throw all of it (the snow) from the room (B5:195); kúlla mṭéla tàma |  They all arrived there (B2:8); l-kúlla d-ày |  overall, in general (B5:115).

kulfət.entry: ʾu-náše xamɛ́wa kúlla kúlfət m-ġðàðe |  All the family lived together (B5:200); kulpət xətna the family of the groom; kulpatti my family, my wife; kúl kúlfət y-azáwa l-míθe dìye |  Every family went to his (the head of the family’s) dead (B5:57).

kulliya.gloss: head of maize (xəṭṭe romaye, xəṭṭe šemaye)

kun.entry: kun ʾaθya t-la xoraθa I hope she will come without her friends (C2:16)

kupala.entry: ʾína kupáli píšla šmìṭṭa |  My stick has broken (A37:17).

k̭uprana.entry: This stands separately in a field or is built over the roof of a porch (gariθət ṣopiθa)

kurənja.gloss: long stick used for carding flax or wool

kurize.gloss: a type of millet (prage) that ripens slowly

kursa.entry: málla hóle tíwa gu-kúrsa ṭlìle |  The mullah sat in a chair and fell asleep (A2:3); kúrsət ṭaləbùθa |  the betrothal chair (A32:11)

kurtəxta.entry: kupəšlux ʾəlli kurtəxyaθa You have gathered to me pelvises (of women) (A52:26).

kuša.entry: This hangs and pulls wool from the distaff (xarnɛsa). The wool is moistened. A large spindle (kuša goṛa) is used for making wool and a smalll spindle (kuša zora) for making thin threads. ʾazla-kuše dragonfly (spinner of spindles, so-called because it rotates around water)

kuspa dəbbe.entry: used for wrapping the filling of dolma

kut.entry: (1) each, every | kut-yàrxa |  each month (A24:5); kut-ṭéna each load (B5:181); kút-xa y-azə́lwa bɛ̄θ-dìye |  Every person went to his home (B5:18); zonə́xwa kút-xa xà |  We would each buy one (B10:76); kút kəma-šə̀nne |  every few years (B10:59); kut-yom every day; kuššət (< kut-šat) every year.; (2) whoever | kút mɛ̀θela |  t-yánne zúze ràba |  Whoever brings her, I shall give him a lot of money (A27:18).

kutəlθa.entry: kutlaθət bəsra meat cutlets, kutlaθət rəzza, kutlaθət gurgur, kutlaθət gəllale.

kuvi.entry: ʾaw-yalúnka zòra |  kùvi-wewa |  The young child was shy (B17:3).

kwara.entry: consisting of willow branches (xelape) covered with clay. It has a hole (ʾɛnta), plugged with a cloth, from which the wheat is taken.

k̭ăbani.entry: k̭ăbanət bɛθa housekeeper, woman in charge of house

k̭ačune.entry: k̭ačúne xá-gaya b-yárxa hàyyo |  Come at least once a month.

k̭awčo.entry: This is used for serving butter (məšxa) on the dish known as gərðo. It is deeper than the spoon known as barxošta.

k̭ora.entry: Dáwəð k̭òra |  blind David (A16:2); ʾɛ́ne díye wíðəlla k̭òre |  He made his eye blind (A16:2); ʾáp-ʾana dàqrən |  ʾax-déwa k̭òra |  I am worth the same as a blind wolf (A10:1); Idioms: k̭óre ʾàna |  May I (f.) be blind (= Oh woe to me, poor me!) (A18:25); k̭óre brátət k̭òre |  poor girl (literally: blind girl, daughter of a blind girl) (A52:5); má-lux k̭óra Xarə̀pša? |  What is the matter with you poor soul, Xarəpša? (A31:9).

k̭učke.entry: mur-ṭla-Zìne |  k̭účke mtagəbràla |  Go down and tell Zine to prepare the living room (A26:46).

k̭ulčiva.entry: piece of wood holding the trap open

k̭ura.gloss: two- to three-year old male goat

k̭urra.entry: k̭urra xamra la-štile Boy, do not drink the wine (C2:10)

k̭wina.entry: made of goat’s hair, used by bedouin Arabs (cf. čadra tent made of fabric): mə́xyela k̭winày |  They pitched their tents (A29:40).

la.entry: ṣə̀lyela |  swánət ʾúmra la-qámθa díya ràmta-wawa |  They (the sheep) went down over the eaves of the church, the front side of which was high (B18:6). Used mainly in adverbial expressions: la-qáma forwards; la-bára backwards; kú mənná ṱ-íle pláṭa mən-gawàye, |  pláṭa la-qam-tằra |  Each one who goes out from inside, going towards the outside (B11:8); y-azíwa la-zràqət yóma |  They would go in the direction of the rising of the sun (A8:22); hóle ʾə́θya Déwa Zàr |  ... m-la-gnay-yòma |  Dewa Zar has come ... from the West (A28:14); ʾɛ́we ʾən-θéla m-la-Zàwa, |  ṱ-áθe xa-yóma ṭàwa |  If the clouds come from the side of the Zab (i.e. the East), a good day will come (D2:16); hola θela m-la-Maye Look she has come from the direction of Maye (C2:46).

la.2.gloss: no (variants laʾ, laʾa), not; neither/nor; asseverative particle.
la.2.entry: (1) no | mə́ra là |  ʾáti ṣli-be-màlka |  They said ‘No, you go down to the house of the king’ (A25:87); mə́re bráti lá là! |  He said ‘My daughter, no, no!’ (A21:30); mə́re làʾ! |  He said ‘No!’ (A1:6); ʾámər làʾa! |  He says ‘No!’ (A21:42).; (2) not | la-ṣábrəx ṱ-òrəx |  We do not dare enter (A14:40); lə́mu la-qìmlux? |  Why did you not stand? (A26:48); bróni là qəṭlúle! |  Do not kill my son! (A33:6); ʾána lɛ̀-gorən, |  la-ʾàti gáwrət |  I shall not marry, so long as you do not marry (A25:83); ʾáni maṣlə́xwa ʾə̀rxe, |  ṭaxnə̀xwala, |  là kúlla náše |  bas-ʾàxni |  ‘We brought them down to the water-mill and ground them, not everybody, but we did (this) (B10:88). Negating an adjective: fə́lfəl ... là-xšilta uncrushed pepper (B10:21).; (3) la ... la neither ... nor | ʾána làn dmíxa, |  là-b-lele, |  là-b-yoma |  I have not slept, neither at night nor during the day (A24:24); ʾána lànwa wíða |  là xarbayúθa |  là spayúθa ṭla-čú-naša |  I have done neither evil nor good to anybody (A14:23); lá-băyəx la-mìya |  ʾu-la-čù-məndi |  We want neither water nor anything else (A39:12).; (4) asseverative particle | la-hóle mìθa |  He is indeed dead (A17:2); A: štélux čàyux? |  B: la-štèli! A: Have you drunk your tea? B: Indeed I have drunk it!

lagăna.entry: séra píšle lagằna |  The moon is full.

lagna.entry: blue in colour, producing seeds known as ṣəṣṣe in thorny pods (bubre, bar-xoxe), both the seeds and the root being edible.

lampa.entry: lámpət gúda ... lámpət ʾìða |  wall lamp ... hand lamp (B10:83)

lana.entry: ku-zmarta lana gana Every song (has) a tune of its own (C1:13)

lappa.gloss: palm (of hand), sole (of foot). (pl. lappe) wave

lappəkθa.gloss: paw (of small animal); foot/hand of small child

laqqa.entry: kálba mxéle láqqa bìyi |  The dog snapped at me.

lašša.gloss: corpse, carcass (which is cut up) (gušma = body of living person, animal)

lata.entry: síqli b-áyya làta |  I went up on this path; šəmša mxela gu-lata The sun has shone on the mountain path (C1:23); mxéle latàθa He made furrows (with a plough to mark the outline of the ploughing area) → lena

laṭṭa.entry: qəm-dɛrɛ́tuli ðá-duka làṭṭe |  You threw me into a shallow place (A7:22); dréle ʾixála qa-ṱ-àxəl |  gu-ʾamána làṭṭa |  He served food for him to eat in a shallow vessel (A45:1).

lăvăna.entry: used to convey steam to a condenser in the distilling of arak.

law.entry: only used in concessive constructions: wắ-law ṱ-ín ʾanna-xámša šə́nne zíla b-dùnye, |  nə́mu lat-ðàʾəlli? |  Although I have been away in the world for these five years, do you not know me any more? (A12:65)

lawaša.gloss: large thin bread baked in an oven

lawlaba.gloss: wooden stick at the two ends of the frame carrying the churn (guða); trigger of gun
lawlaba.entry: l-ʾiðe drele lawlaba He put his hand on the trigger (C7:11)

laxoma.entry: ṭla d-aw dosta laxoma for that handsome friend of hers (C2:75)

laxxa.entry: hóla làxxa |  They are here (A14:100); mút ʾáti tíwta làxxa? |  Why are you sitting here? (A25:58); háyyo làxxa! |  Come here! (A13:6); ʾáyya xá-šeta hóla támma láxxa lɛ́la mbaqorə̀llux |  It has been a year that they have been here without asking for you (A26:78).

laxxane.entry: mắnile mə́ṣya zədyəlléy laxxàne? |  Who could have thrown them here? (A8:15)

lazəm.entry: Deontic: lázəm ʾaxlə̀nne |  I must eat him (A47:5). Epistemic: ʾánna madám-ṱ-ila ʾátxa jwánqe w-átxa tàze, |  lázəm ʾaw-xə́lmi pàləṭ |  If they are so beautiful and so fine, that dream of mine must come true (A7:7); ʾu-xa-mašmóye-wewa ʾəllɛ̀ni lázəm |  Somebody must have been listening to us (A35:19).

leba.entry: záwnət lèbewa |  It was the time of tricks (A1:24); lá-băye ṱ-awə́ðwa lèbe |  He did not want to play tricks (A29:36).

lebana.entry: záwna lebàna-wewa |  ... wélux lebána ʾàx-zawna |  The time was tricky ... You became tricky like the time (A1:22).

lena.gloss: furrow made by plough used as outline marks to guide the ploughing
lena.entry: mxaya lenane, draya lenane to mark furrows → lata

leta.entry: letət kɛrma terraced vineyard built on mountain side

lɛle.entry: pɛšíwa xá-lɛle trè |  They stayed for a night or two (B5:234); ʾɛ́-ga b-lɛ́le tíwəx kəs-xáli d-àni |  That night we sat with my uncle and his family (B15:57); wítɛla b-lɛ̀le |  maláxa mŭṛə́šle qa-ràbbən |  In the night (literally: It became in the night) the angel woke the monk (A15:11); píšla b-lɛ̀le, |  sìqɛle |  l-gàre. |  In the night (literally: It became in the night), he went up onto the roof (A25:52); mə́dre ʾi-zamŕwa-w šatɛ̀wa |  hál y-oráwa gu-lɛ̀le |  They again sang and drank until it was night (literally: until it passed into night) (B5:18); m-lɛle early morning, before dawn; ʾədlɛle tonight.

lɛša.entry: ʾíman-t qámxa lɛšíle lɛ̀ša |  when they knead flour into a dough (B6:45)

ləbba.gloss: heart; kernel of fruit or berry
ləbba.entry: Idioms: yawa ləbba l- to console (after death), to encourage: híwɛle lə́bba ṭla-gʸáne dìye |  He took heart (A8:58). ləbbi zille l-d-ɛ qumta I fainted at the sight of that figure (C2:55). bəd-lə́bba gu-bɛ́θət bába dìyɛla |  She thinks that she is in her father’s house (A21:18). gu-lə́bbe díye mtuxmə̀nne |  I thought to himself (A39:5). lə́bbe biyáxu tlìqetu |  He thinks you are lost (A14:85). dwiqále b-lə̀bbe |  He kept it in mind. ʾáyya quṣárta ràba šapirta, |  rába zála ləbbì-ʾəlla |  This cooking pot is very nice, I like it a lot (A5:2); hóle zála lə̀bbi |  ṱ-ásqət ṣɛ́dət ʾə́rbət wàla |  I would like you to go up and hunt for wild sheep (A26:44). lə́bbi basìma |  I am happy. ʾáwwa náša lə́bbe pqìle |  The heart of that burst (= He was terrified) (A32:2). qìdle lə́bbi, |  xóni zòra-wewa |  My heart yearned (for him), he was my young brother (A34:24); mən-lə́bbe díye qìða, |  dɛ́re xɛ̀la, |  načə̀lle ʾo-šəryóxa |  Out of his fervour, he applied force and pulled the tether apart (A28:20). xílli lə̀bbux |  My dear, you are dear to me (A39:12). ʾána hóle píša lə̀bbi |  I am angry. t-la-páyəš lə́bbən b-ġðàðe |  so that we do not feel anger at each other (B5:10); ṭḷàθna |  xonăwáθət Qára Tèždin |  mopíšəlle ləbbèy |  The three brothers of Qara Teždin became angry (A26:71). ʾánna píšla gu-lə́bbe díye kùlla |  All these (words) weighed on his heart (A38:13). ʾáyya lɛ̀ða, |  lə́bba ṣə̀pya žáre |  She did not know, she was innocent, poor thing (A14:99). hátxa baṣlóṣe gu-lə́bbət nàša |  (They) glow in the heart of man (= they captivate one’s heart) (A8:16). m-kúlla lə́bbi bắyən ʾána qaṭlìtuli |  With all my heart I want you to kill me (B9:14).

ləbbana.entry: kálba gu-tắrət màre |  ləbbàna y-áwe |  A dog at the door of his owner is brave (D2:64)

ləngo.entry: xáθi θèli |  ʾítle ṭḷáθa ʾaqlàθa, |  lə́ngo lə̀ngo |  hal-tàmma |  Sister, I came here, while it (my horse) had three legs, limping up to here (A18:20).

ləxma.entry: lə́xma šaxína daṛmánət náša kpìna |  Hot bread is the medicine of a hungry man (D2:69). šáqla xa-lə̀xma |  She would buy a loaf of bread (A10:6); ʾína xáze ʾə́sri ʾə́č̣č̣a lə̀xme |  He saw that there were twenty-nine loaves of bread (A17:12); lə́xmən xaràmile |  Our bread is outlawed (i.e. we are unpopular); ləxmət maθ-Maryam, ləxmət maθ-Maryam St. Mary’s bread (name of herb).

lišana.entry: lišana ʾarabaya the Arabic language; qəm-maxɛ́le lišanèy |  They licked him (A18:31); npílle lišána b-sɛ̀pa |  The sword started to talk (A52:22).

lo.entry: Zìne nábləx kəs-Mắmo |  lo-Mằmo nábləx kəs-Zíne? |  Should we take Zine to Mămo or Mămo to Zine? (A26:2); xázəx mhayríli lo-làʾa |  Let us see whether they will help me or not (A48:2); lo-ṱ-axláli də̀bba |  lo-palṭèna |  Either the bear will eat me or I shall get out (A20:11).

lxima.entry: xzi-kəmɛ́le lxìma! |  Look how fit he is! (A15:13)

ma.entry: xúwwe mà ṱ-áwəð b-an-álpa dáwe? |  What will the snake do with those thousand gold coins? (A1:8); xáθi mà-ləx? |  Sister, what is the matter with you? (A34:12); mà-lux zə́dya? |  Why are you afraid? (A11:6); má-lux mə́nne ʾàti? |  What business is it of yours? (A32:3); ʾána má-li mə̀nnux? |  What have I to do with you? (A32:22); má-ləx bráta ṱ-it-hátxa bxàya |  What is the matter with you girl that you are weeping so much? (A34:20); sállət míya yắðət mɛ̀la? |  (< mà-ila) Do you know what a basket of water is? (A16:10). Modifier of a noun: ʾánna ma-brinànela gu-réšux |  What wounds are these on your head? (A29:6). Exclamatory modifier of a noun: ʾu-Bə́lbəl Hazár yăðátla ma-báxta xàmθɛla |  You know what a beautiful woman Bəlbəl Hazar is (A8:65). Expressing an exclamatory proposition: ma-píštət k̭awə̀lla! |  How you have become a ruin! (A18:16). With remonstrating force in negated questions ma-lat-ðáya b-gánəx qàrθɛla? |  Don’t you know yourself that it is cold?! (A20:1). Before imperatives: ma-yəmmi pɛli zwaðe Mother, bake me supplies! (A50:9). Before a repeated noun to express a more general class (§14.11.): jawə́tta ṭla-pràma |  ʾanna qɛ́se ma-qɛ̀se |  A chopper was for chopping wood and the like (B5:141).

madam.entry: introduces factual conditions (§19.5.7.): mádam hàtxɛla |  ṱ-ázən ṭắyən báθər ḥaqqùθa |  ʾu-na-ḥaqqùθa |  If (the world) is like that, I shall go and search for what is lawful and what is unlawful (A15:5).

madənxa.entry: jálde qam-mxɛ́θət madə̀nxa |  early before sunrise (A8:51); qímɛle jálde madə́nxa t-la-mxàya |  He rose early while the dawn was not breaking (= before dawn broke) (A8:51); txúme díye ʾìla |  mən-madə̀nxa |  Zàwa, |  ʾu-mən-màrwa |  ʾìla |  Xawòra |  Its borders are, on the East, the Zab and, on the West, the Khabur (B1:4).

mað̣ira.gloss: dish made of dawwe and rice

măḥalle.entry: ʾap-a-măḥálle tlixàle |  and he destroyed the district (A29:53); ʾɛ́kɛle măḥálle dìye? |  Where is his shop? (A16:3).

măjāl.entry: măjā́l xa-ʾə́šta šáwwa yòme |  ṱ-axlə́nne xáčča bə̀sra |  (Give me) the space of six or seven days, so that I can eat some meat (A24:48); qč̣ipewəx mqorəč̣pewəx |  t-la-b-hewən ʾu-t-la măjalən |  We are cut down and harvested not in the season nor in our time (for cutting) (A51:8).

majbur.entry: páyəš májbur béna xaráya šàte |  In the end it will be forced to drink (A12:47); píšɛle májbur ṣə̀lyɛle |  He had to dismount (A28:33); ʾáti májbur t-yàtli rə́sqi |  You will be obliged to give me my sustenance (A10:3).

majma.entry: ʾáy šwíqtəlwa májma tàma |  She had left a tray there (A4:53).

majo.gloss: wide bowl for kneading dried yoghurt cakes (qaške)

makrəb č̭uč̭ane.gloss: late snow falling at the beginning March
makrəb č̭uč̭ane.entry: Literally: the one that angers the magpies

malapa.entry: hóla ʾarbí malàpe |  There are forty sheets (A24:17)

maləkθa.entry: ṱ-óya malə́kθa b-šópi ʾíman-t-ʾána mɛ̀θən |  She will be queen in my place when I die (A4:39).

malka.entry: qɛsət malka wood of the king, a type of wood from which spoons were made (B10:100); ʾilanət malka the tree from which such wood is taken.

malkuθa.entry: mən-ə̀dyo |  malkùθa |  m-bnónux qằṭa |  From today the kingship will be cut off from your sons (A8:96).

ṃaḷyana.entry: ṃaḷyànɛle That is enough; ṃaḷyànɛle ʾixálux? Do you have enough food?

malyəzana.entry: lá-hawət malyəzàna! |  Do not be hasty (A8:43)

mamðana.entry: mar Yoḥanna mamðana St. John the Baptist

maməkka.entry: tre yalone havrəkke šarreley rəš-mamməkke two rival children are fighting on the breasts (C2:39)

manay.entry: hadíya ðíli ʾána manáy díyux mòdila |  Now I know what you mean (A17:35).

măni.entry: mằniwət? |  Who are you? (A23:26); ʾánna tre-yále mắnile mə́ṣya dəryə́lla gu-šaqìθa? |  Who could have put these two children in the stream? (A8:15).

manquš.gloss: fire steel, metal instrument for striking fire on flint

mapšəmana.entry: xa-qə́ṣṣət rába mapšəmàntɛla |  It is a very sad story (A4:31).

măqamta.entry: măqámtət ʾə̀rbe the raising of sheep

maqərxana.entry: (1) brush for whitewashing | hóle maqróxe gudáne b-maqərxàna |  He is whitewashing the wools with a brush.; (2) metal-polisher | kut-šayə́šla šə́rme lɛ́le makərxàna |  Everybody who shakes his buttocks is not a metal-polisher (D2:75).

maqlūb.entry: nále l-koðənyaθéy mə́xyəlla bə̀-l-maqlūb |  They put on the shoes of their mules back to front (B4:13)

maqora.gloss: hole cut out of middle of stew to hold syrop (napoxta, nepoxta)
maqora.entry: ʾó-t mɛθéwa bušàla |  be-pálge díye y-awə́ðwale maqòra y-amrə́xle |  Whoever brought stew would make what we call a ‘hole’ in the middle of it (B5:67). Normally the hole was filled with syrop (napoxta, nepoxta).

maqul.entry: wéləx hawnànta, |  b-ʾiqárət ṣáwθa basìmta, |  ʾu-màqul |  You have been clever, with the gift of sweet and fine words (A40:16)

mara.entry: marət bɛθa householder, landlord; kɛ̀le mára d-áyya? |  Where is the owner of this (ring)? (A4:19); t-lá marăwàθɛle ʾo-márga |  ṱ-it-súsux də́ryəlle tàma? |  Is the meadow in which you have put your horse without owners? (A25:60). Pl. parents | ʾánna tre-yále qəm-xazə̀nna |  t-la marwàθa |  I have found these two children, without parents (A8:16); sáʾət ṭḷàθa |  qèdamta |  măṛəšíwalən marăwàθən |  At three o’clock in the morning our parents used to wake us (B15:2); t-la-rzáyət marăwáθa dìya |  without the consent of her parents.

mărād.entry: mărádət lə̀bbux |  maməṭyànnux |  I shall make you attain your heart’s desire (A33:10).

marimana.entry: especially lever of a water mill (ʾərxe) raised in order to control the turning of the millstone → marmana

măṛiya.entry: maṛiyət ʾərbe pasture ground of sheep

măṛiyana.entry: măṛiyanət ʾərwe pasturer of small cattle

marrəs.gloss: wool of the long haired angora goat (čura, čurra)
marrəs.entry: ʾərwət marrəs goat with such hair

marta.entry: ʾáyya mártət ʾamàre |  This is what they say (literally: This is the saying of the sayers) (A32:24)

marta.2.entry: marθət bɛθa mistress of the house; Mat Maryam (< Mart) St. Mary. In attributive expressions: šəṭro marθət habriya the beautiful woman who possesses the headscarf (C2:1).

marya.entry: márya ʾálaha Lord God; yá-marya ʾàlaha |  O Lord God (A10:3).

marza.entry: marzət nera the bank of a river; l-márzət yàma |  the shore of the sea (A12:27); t-yatwanwa l-marzət gəšra I would sit on the edge of the bridge (C3:2)

marzaban.entry: kúlla maθwáθə ṱ-íla marzabánət ʾƐ̄n-Nùne |  all the villages that were around Ɛn Nune (B15:61).

marzaq.gloss: wooden stick covered in wool used to stick bread to the oven

mašana.gloss: beam connecting yoke to the main body of the plough

maše.entry: xa dandəkθət maše a single bean; šənqət maše bean pod

masəxθa.gloss: metal poker for fire; branding iron; frying pan

maši.entry: mášila zála də̀bba |  The bear was walking (A27:13)

măṣixət šərmət kθayaθa.entry: Literally: the tester of the behind of chickens, i.e. the finger that one inserts into a chicken to test whether it is bearing an egg→ m-ṣyx III.

masrəqta.gloss: comb (for hair); comb for filtering the water passing through a pipe leading to a water-mill
masrəqta.entry: la-ṣále b-čú masrə̀qθa |  He cannot be combed down with any comb (D2:76);

masrəqθonta.entry: hállila masrəqθònti |  Give me my little comb (A34:3)

mata.entry: hálli ða-máta mən-d-aw-gùjma |  Give me a grape from that bunch

maṭo.entry: (1) how? | máṭo mṭèlux? |  How have you come? (A18:18); de-màṭo hóya? |  How could that be? (A30:21); ʾána máṭo mṣárən ṭla-yə̀mme |  yə́mme díye yə̀mmi-wawa? |  How can I curse his mother, since his mother was my mother? (A32:31); màṭowət? How are you?; (2) How could it be? | quṣárta màṭo mabə́rya?! |  How can it be that a cooking pot has given birth?! (A5:6)

maṭoya.entry: prage maṭoye a type of millet that ripens quickly

mawəlka.gloss: type of small sledge hammer with fine head

mawmiθa.entry: méli rába mawmàθa |  I swore many oaths

maxbana.entry: maxbánət gàne-wewa |  He was a lover of himself (= selfish) (A3:1).

maxjəlana.entry: wéle xa-xábra maxjəlàna |  It was a terrifying piece of news (B1:13).

maxkɛθa.entry: la-mháymnət kul-maxkɛ́θa basìmta |  Do not believe every sweet speech (A49:6).

maxmore.entry: xo-qðala maxmore on her neck are jewels (C6:4)

mayoya.gloss: long wooden rod runnning the length of the frame carryng the churn (guða) → lawlaba.

mayuθa.entry: mayuθət reša crown of the head

măzada.entry: dɛrɛ́wa măzàde |  They would hold auctions (B8:38)

mazaxa.gloss: area below the millstones in a water-mill onto which the flour falls

mazdiyana.entry: xzéli xa-xə̀lma |  rába mazdiyàna |  I had a very frightening dream (A11:6)

mazyatta.entry: mšɛrìwa ... mazyàtta |  They would start the bidding (B5:8)

maʾarwa.entry: txúme díye ʾìla |  mən-madə̀nxa |  Zàwa, |  ʾu-mən-màrwa |  ʾìla |  Xawòra |  Its borders are, on the East, the Zab and, on the West, the Khabur (B1:4)

maʾayša.entry: mút maʾáyša muttàli? |  What earnings did I make? (A23:40)

maθa.entry: maθət ʾƐ̄n-Nune the village of ʾƐn-Nune (B1:9); rešət maθa the head of the village; ʾíθwalən šawwá ʾabòne |  gu-máθa dìyən |  We had seven bishops in our village (B2:6).

maθyana.entry: maθyánət xárje-w bárjət boṭanàye |  the collector of taxes and the like of the people of Botan (A26:34).

mbaqrana.entry: wí mbaqràna, |  ṱ-áwət yaðùwa |  If you are inquisitive, you shall be knowledgeable (D2:11)

mədre.entry: mə́dre xzéle xə̀lma |  He had a dream again (A1:9); ʾína lɛ́wa mə́dre gnàyux |  But again it was not your fault (A1:25).

məjja.gloss: yoghurt paste made by dissolving dried yoghurt cakes (qaške)

məjjəd.entry: b-álaha xónən-it mə̀jjəd |  By God, you are really our brother (A39:8); ʾáyya bèna |  ʾə́n ʾamrə̀nnux |  pălə́tla pálga mə̀jjəd? |  This time, if I tell you, will you really divide them in half? (A1:12).

məlka.entry: mə́lkət gáne dìyela |  They were his property (B4:2).

məllət.entry: mə́llət kúlla sqìdla |  The whole community is fed up (A32:9); mə́llət ʾaθoràye |  the Assyrian nation (B6:21).

məlməlawa.gloss: celebrations at the end of winter
məlməlawa.entry: custom practised at the end of the month of February, in which a bonfire is made and children go around the village asking for small gifts, also know as bəlbəlawa.

məlxawa.entry: made of wood, including the teeth

ṃəḷya.entry: ṃə́ḷya dùša |  full of honey (A14:14); díwən-t málka hóle ṃḷíθa náše ràbe |  The audience chamber of the king is full of many people (A17:31); ða-ʾilàna |  hóla rš-rúše dìye |  ṃḷíθɛla mən-rə́jbət ʾằra |  a tree is on his shoulder, full of wildlife (A12:3); dúnye qímla ṃə̀ḷye it is raining torrentially.

məndi.entry: ʾána ʾáxxa nšéli xa-mə̀ndi |  I have forgotten something here (B5:35); ʾáθət ʾána mbàšlən mə́ndi |  Come and I shall cook something (A22:14); rába mə́ndi ṭemàna a lot of valuable stuff (A7:9); ʾíθwale mə́ndi ràba |  He had a lot (A26:63); ʾu-xáčča ṭína məndì |  and a little mud or the like (B5:190); ʾaw-lá-ʾaxəl čú-mdi He would eat nothing (A2:4); ʾáp-xa mənnɛ́xu lɛ́le l-zmárta xa-mə̀ndi? |  Is anyone of you for a song or something? (A35:7)

mənta.entry: hon-ṭyána mə́nta mə̀nnux |  / ʾána ṭɛnánət mə̀ntɛwən |  You have done me a favour (I am much obliged to you).

merəkka.entry: the object of this is to hit a small stone as far as possible with a broad stone

mərtoxa.gloss: filling made of wheat flour mixed with butter
mərtoxa.entry: the more usual term used in Barwar is duwana.

mɛša.entry: produces ʾapṣe (gallnuts) and baluṭe (acorns); also known as ʾilanət ʾapṣe gallnut tree. It is related to the trees known as p̣aṛma and zədyana.

məskena.entry: b-núrət rašíye y-áqði məskène |  By the fire of wicked people the poor burn (D2:73)

məšna.entry: məšna ʾu-baṭila a whetstone and horn (of butter for lubrication)

məššara.gloss: section of a paddy field, paddy field basin

məṣṭaqa.gloss: shelf in a chicken-coop (qare) on which chickens sit

məšṭaxa.gloss: area where fruit and vegetables were spread out to dry

məstik.gloss: mosquito net (supported by one pole or by four poles)

məšwanəkke.entry: referring properly to the cover of the cylindrical baskets (sălămeše) in which the bees are kept.

məšxa.gloss: vegetable oil; clarified butter (from yoghurt or milk)
məšxa.entry: mə́šxa ḥùr |  (B5:31), mə́šxa hòr (B16:12) pure butter; máxa xa-mə́šxa gu-be-ʾéne dìye |  (The priest and deacon) put some oil on his forehead (B6:36)

məšxana.gloss: paste made from oil. adj. (f. məšxanta, pl. məšxane) oily

məṭra.entry: ṣléla mə̀ṭra |  Rain fell (A11:18); mə̀ṭrɛla |  It is rainy; mə́ṭra mṭárɛla ràba |  There is a lot of rain; məṭra xɛlanta heavy rain.

mətxa.entry: gu-mə́txət xa-daqìqa |  wéla lháya ʾan-qɛ̀se |  Within the space of one minute those pieces of wood ignited (B15:24)

mevan.entry: pɛšənwa mevan diya (If only) I could become her guest (C2:1)

məxra.gloss: small water channel carrying water across field boundaries (gevanane)

meydān.entry: ṣadra meydān t-Barčalla Her chest (is like) the plain of Barčalla (C2:44).

mhɛmənana.entry: mhamənána b-ʾalàha |  a believer in God (A16:3).

mila.entry: mə́xyəxəlla máθən kúlla l-míla-w l-kóma We have covered all our village with blue and black (A4:32); míla b-rešɛ̀xu! |  Confound you! (literally: Blue on your head!) (A7:14); míla l-hàlux! |  Confound you! (literally: Blue on your condition!) (A23:10). adj. (pl. mile, no f. form used) blue/green; xa rapə yawne mile A flock of blue doves (C2:35).

mirata.entry: bɛ́θa d-áwwa náša píšle miràta |  The house of this man has no heirs

miroṭa.entry: ʾipyáθa mən-miròṭela |  The straps (of the plough) are made of gut

miruθa.gloss: nobility, the office of a lord

miya.entry: miya qarire cold water; míya hóla rθàxa |  The water is boiling; šalqo t-miya chicken-pox.

miθəkka.gloss: a child dressed up in white clothes who is taken around houses of the village at Christmas, or a model of a child dressed and carried in this way (B16:13ff.)

mkase qərṭale.gloss: late snow falling at the end of March

mnaxa.entry: mnáxət bábi my father, may he rest in peace; my late father (B3:4)

mola.gloss: partitioned storage area in a goma (basement stable)

moza.gloss: must (unfermented juice) of grapes; residue of grapes after distillation of arak

moʿəd.entry: ṭḷáθna hon-yíwtəlla mòʿəd |  I have made an appointment with the three of them (A22:21)

mrariya.entry: gudane bani kepa xwara mrariya They will build the walls white stone and marble. (C3:9)

mreriya.entry: qðalə kʸalo mreriye On the neck of the bride there are bangles (C5:10)

mrupya.entry: heywáne mrùpyewa gu-góma |  The animals were untethered in the basement stable.

msarbəs.gloss: wooden instrument on which balls of wool are wound → srbs

msɛθa.entry: ʾitla msɛθa She is having a menstrual period (literally: She has washing, i.e. washing of the soiled clothes).

mṣoθa.gloss: extract from ʾatko (piece of the stomach of a young goat) used as rennet (marɛθa) for cheese

mšaxəlpana.gloss: somebody who keeps changing his mind

mṣɛθa.entry: mattìwa |  ṱ-ámrəx xá xámša dinàre |  ʾən-hàtxa mə́ndi |  yáʿni ʾax-mṣɛ̀θa |  They would deposit let us say a sum of five dinars, or thereabouts, according to their ability (to pay) (B5:6)

mšurəšya.entry: garíθa mšuršɛ̀θɛla |  The roof (of the outhouse) is sloping.

mtarəksana.entry: cf. badoda long wooden poker, maṣəxθa metal poker

mučəkθa.gloss: dry measure in the form of a small bowl (used by the owner of water-mill to measure out his share of the flour for his fee)

mujarrad.entry: bas-mjárrad mṣawθàwa |  She was just talking (A19:9)

muka.gloss: wooden post hammered into the ground to make a wattle fence

mur.entry: məxyále mur-dìye |  He put his stamp (on it).

murja.entry: used for breaking stones and hewing rock, larger than a mawəlka which is used for the same purpose.

musarde.gloss: festival commemorating the baptism of Christ (100 days after Easter)

mziða.gloss: bag for storing grain (made of sheepskin)

naðorta.gloss: pipe running out from a spring (ʾɛna) or an irrigation channel (šaqiθa)

năfăr.entry: After numerals: ʾəč̣č̣ì nắfăre |  ninety people (B2:10).

naftang.entry: ʾaqláθe díye píše kèpa |  hál naftánge dìye |  His legs had turned to stone up to his waist (A8:58).

na-ḥaqquθa.entry: ṱ-ázən ṭắyən báθər ḥaqqùθa |  ʾu-na-ḥaqqùθa |  I shall go and search for what is lawful and what is unlawful (A15:5)

nahira.entry: used in the lamps of churches (nuṭa being used in house lamps); nahirət šəšme sesame oil for lamps, nahirət gawze walnut oil for lamps, nahirət bəṭme terebinth oil for lamps

na-mumkən.entry: ʾo-t-là páləx |  na-múmkən ṱ-áxəl gu-bɛ̀θi |  Whoever does not work cannot eat in my house (A21:40).

napaxta.gloss: a large hollow measure for corn in the form of open oblong wooden box

napoxta.entry: In the Barwar region it was always made of raisins.

naqiða.entry: qɛsa naqiða thin wood; zolale naqiðe fine tendrils

naqruza.gloss: beak (of birds); proboscis (of flies, wasps, bees, etc.)
naqruza.entry: č̣éne šádli naqruzéy gu-gə́ldət heywàne |  Mosquitoes stick their proboscis into the skin of animals.

năra.2.entry: ʾay-wàðtɛla |  năra-nắra dìya |  She was roaring (A27:14).

nardumana.entry: báxti nardumàntɛla, |  lá-băya ʾàrxe |  My wife is miserable, she does not want guests.

năreθa.gloss: small axe; piece in shape of an axe at the end of the rotating shaft that fits into the upper grindstone of a water-mill

narṭuma.entry: narṭúmə sùsa |  the snout of the horse (A12:65)

nasarta.entry: nasartət ʾiða hand saw; nasartət dape large saw used by two people for cutting planks (dape) from logs.

năṣiyət.entry: xa-năṣíyət t-yánna ṭlàlux |  I’ll give you some advice (A24:9).

naša.entry: bəṛ-naša human being; málla mə́re náša šùqla! |  The mullah said ‘Man, give me a break!’ (A2:6); nášət kʸàlo |  the family of the bride (B5:36); xa-nàši |  a relative of mine (A18:16).

našuθa.entry: ʾáyya bráta hon-ʾə́θya nablə̀nna |  ʾən-b-našùθa, |  ʾən-b-xɛ̀la |  I have come to take this girl, either humanely or by force (A29:65).

naveže.entry: lázəm ʾáθe ʾáwəð navèže |  He must come to make ablutions (A25:33).

nawba.entry: nawbət miya turn for a field to receive irrigation water, determined by the irrigation manager (karaxa); so-dúqu nàwba |  Go and keep guard (A18:3).

nazik.entry: Nàze, |  ʾáti gánəx nàzik-iwət |  Naze, you yourself are delicate (A25:18); ʾə́rwe năwazìk-ila |  Sheep are delicate (B10:56).

naθa.entry: gúda máre naθyàθɛle |  The wall has ears (D2:43); náθux lè-y-yatla |  l-hàtxa náše mṣáwθi |  Do not give your ear to such people speaking (A26:67); zdímla naθyáθi b-qálət tòpe |  My ears were deafened by a gushot; naθyaθət nunta the gills of a fish, naθyaθət tope the sights of a gun (diagonal pieces attached to the barrel joined by a strip of animal hair).

nčila.entry: y-oðə́xwale júlle nčìle We made for him ragged clothes (B16:10)

neṛa.entry: rába píšle zắbun néṛət ʾɛ̀ne, |  b-xɛ̀lɛle dyála |  His sight has become very weak, he can hardly see.

neriya.gloss: male goat four years old and upwards

nəmu.entry: (1) asseverative particle | In the context of negative questions: nə́mu la-mə́ri-llux dàyəṛ, |  míθa dàyəṛ? |  Did I not tell you that he would return (= indeed I told you ...), that the dead would return? (A22:39); nə́mu la-ʾawðə́xle ʾáwwa ṭùra |  dărajyàθa, |  daràje, |  ṱ-ásqəx l-áwwa ṭùra? |  Should we not make steps for this mountain (= indeed let us make ...), so that we can go up the mountain? (A17:4); lə́mu lá-ʾasqən ʾàna? |  Should I not go? (= indeed I should go) (A39:10).; (2) why? | lə́mu la-qìmlux? |  Why did you not get up? (A26:48).; (3) remonstrating particle | In a positive question: nə́mu ʾáyya bə́rke d-ɛ̀nila |  ṱ-it-ʾáti sxáya gàwa? |  Whose is this pool in which you are swimming? (surely it is mine not yours) (A25:61).

nənxa.entry: mtăməzə́xwa ʾamáne b-qə́ṭma-w nə̀nxa |  We used to clean vessels with ash and mint.

nəqda.entry: ʾo-yóma qăṭíwa nə̀qda |  On that day they would decide on money (B5:8).

nəqša.entry: y-oðíwa nə̀qše gáwa |  t-ʾámṛa kòma |  They made embroideries in them (the rugs) of black wool (B10:79)

nəšma.entry: tá-t šaqlíle nəšmèy |  so that they could take away their soul (A4:59); píšle nə̀šma |  It became a living being (A18:29); kú nə̀šma |  t-màṭya |  rəš-gə́šrət Dalàle |  ʾɛ-nə́šma bəd-pɛ̀ša |  prìmta, |  qṭìlta |  Any soul that comes onto the bridge of Dalale-that soul will be slaughtered, killed (C8:5).

nəšwa.entry: nəšwət qəqwane traps for partridges, consisting of loops (xarbuqyaθa) of horse hair suspended on pruning hooks (čakalyaθa) that are stuck in the ground; nəšwət čučəkke traps for small birds, consisting of loops of horse hair hung up intertwined with a bunch of millet heads (dastət bole); mattoye nəšwe to lay bird traps.

nəxla.gloss: sieved grain; flour that falls through a fine sieve (mxilta)

nimana.entry: bɛθa nimana a damp house; julla nimana a damp cloth; hawa nimana humid air; ʾăra nimanta damp ground

nira.gloss: yoke of a plough; small wooden strip made of juniper laid across beams in a roof (syn. qarša)

nišanqa.entry: wíðɛle ʾa-dúkθa nišànqa |  He made a sign in that place (A11:10); mattíwa nišànqe |  They (the family of the groom) would deposit tokens (of betrothal, usually in the form of a deposit of money) (B5:5).

nita.gloss: dawning of the day, all night celebrations during a wedding
nita.entry: munéla nìta |  Dawn has broken; qaṭlə́xla nìta |  We shall continue our celebrations until dawn.

nixa.entry: nixa nixa slowly, gently: zíla níxa níxa wíra gu-d-a-màθɛle |  He went along slowly and entered the village (A14:58); pálxi plìxe, |  y-áxli nìxe |  Those who have worked hard work but those who are inactive eat (D2:33); tré-mənna tlíxela nìxela |  Two of them (the churces) are destroyed and obliterated (B1:5); ʾána ṣalə́nwa m-d-ó-nixət xòni |  I used to go down with my late brother (B5:212).

nohra.entry: ʾálaha maníxle gu-nóhra ʾu-pardɛ̀sa |  May God grant him rest in light and paradise (said after the death of somebody); šabθət nora The Saturday of Light. This is the Saturday before Easter, so named since the angels went down to the grave of Jesus and bathed it in light.

nṭarta.entry: tiwa wənwa nṭaraθa I was sitting in vigil (C2:16)

nune.gloss: fish; smooth skinned like a fish (name of nanny goat)
nune.entry: ʾə́zza ʾɛ-Nùne the nanny goat called Nune (C7:3)

nura.entry: qa-mó gắrəg ʾázəl kúlla páxri gu-nùra? |  Why should all my body go to Hell fire (A16:2)

nuta.entry: small form of nuwa, consists of a single leaf (ṭaya), which is bitter to the taste; nuta balle type of herb

nuwa.entry: large form of a nuta, consisting of several leaves (ṭaye)

nxilθa.entry: mtuxmə́nne ṱ-áwəð nxìlθa |  He (the fox) thought of doing a mischievous trick (A49:2).

pača.gloss: dish consisting of the head and legs of an animal

pačča.entry: štáyɛle b-pàčča |  He is drinking with his hands

pala.2.entry: qəm-daryáli pàla |  She presented my fortune to me; dréla xa-pàla |  She made a prediction of her fortune (A38:2) → pela

pălakka.entry: marmanne qam-pălakke I shall raise it (the churn) up to the stars (C5:2)

palga.entry: (1) half | xa-w palge one and a half; hálli xa-lə́xma-w pàlge |  Give me one and a half loaves of bread; xa-kista-w palge one and a half bags; ʾánna ʾálpa dáwe pălə̀tla, |  pálga ṭlàli |  pálga ṭlàlux? |  Will you divide those thousand gold pieces, half for me and half for you? (A1:6); ʾap-an-zúze kúlla ṱ-in šqìləlla |  pălə́nna pàlge |  I’ll divide into halves also all the money that I took (A1:17); pálgət ʾùrxɛwəx |  We are halfway (on our journey).; (2) middle | ʾu-b-pálgət bɛ́θa wídla nùra |  She made a fire in the middle of the house (A19:4); palgət yoma midday; kepət palga middle stone (at the top of a door stone). be-palga adv. in the middle | ʾo-yála zóra hóla múttəlle be-pàlga |  They put the little boy in the middle (A4:58); n.m. middle section | ʾap-aqlə-d-àw, |  hál be-palge-díye píša kèpa |  Its leg, up to its middle had become stone (A8:30).

palla.entry: y-oðə́xwa nùra, |  ʾáwwəl ma-t-ràxəθ, |  garšə́xla qɛ̀se, |  pɛ́šiwa pàlle |  We made a fire. As soon as it boiled, we pulled away the wood and it became embers. (B10:87)

palləkθa.gloss: small piece of burning coal, ember

paloxaya.entry: ʾu-plúx mən-d-ànna paloxáye |  Work with these labourers (A24:5).

palpule.entry: kul səmbəlti xa draya, kul zargulti palpulti Each (side) of my moustache is a cubit, and each shoe of mine and each boot of mine (is a cubit) (A51:5).

pandana.entry: θéle téla pandàna |  The cunning fox came (A49:2).
